She exhaled until her ribs ached in the good way, until the part of her that did tallying with words had to stop and trust the count. She counted heartbeats like they were pebbles dropped down a well and listened for them to land. The steam rose in gentle sheets and made the edges of the lane disappear as if the water had decided to draw its own horizon. The lifeguard had a different paperback and the same look that tried on contempt and took it off when she nodded at him like a neighbor. Fifty meters taught her that her shoulders were still hers. Fifty more told her that the body keeps what you teach it even when the brain is ricocheting off furniture.

By the time she got to the station, the city had already done that thing where it turned every miracle into minutes. There was a time slot for press and one for Crown Prosecution and one for the superintendent’s new habit of pre-emptive regret. People had brought their opinions dressed as muffins. The whiteboard had been wiped and re-populated so many times the ghosts of old diagrams gave the new ones a feeling of déjà vu. Lindsey had put Jamie’s dragon on the board in the corner, away from the uglier images, and someone had stuck a yellow dot sticker on its eye; it made the dragon look like it knew a joke it would tell when the room deserved it.

The superintendent did his version of tenderness with his jacket off and his shirt sleeves rolled, the uniform of borrowed informality. He praised the team and then warned them about the aftershocks, about the thousand small ways cases like this bleed and seep. The parade committee had called at seven to say the word shadow in a way that meant money and risk and memory. An alderman had left a message that alternated between talking points and an old man’s fear of the city changing so fast his bones couldn’t keep up. A journalist with hair you trusted despite yourself had requested five minutes with the detective who swam, because the swimming made it human. She declined gracefully, with a sentence that made an apology and a boundary hold hands.

They charged Leonard—Lenard on paper, which felt right in the way that petty errors sometimes do—with child abduction and a raft of other offenses that made the CPS lawyer rub at his eye as if clarity could be coaxed out with skin. There would be more, after the techs finished building their delicate scaffolds. The peppermint oil on the pies would become a metaphor in court; she could see the jurors smelling it in the air even if the courtroom smelled only of heating and old carpet. The chalk dust in the annex would be a quiet weather system over the barrister’s head. The door codes, the ledgers from Jasko’s, the rabbit-skin glue, the canvases facing inward, the list of flags: each would be carried like a tile and laid down in a floor the jury could cross without falling into the river of the defense’s insistence that nothing had been personal.

His flat, when they got to it, was almost an essay. He had made arguments with the furniture. Chairs in pairs, each equidistant from the table as if they could measure decency. A line of brushes in glasses as precise as soldiers at inspection. A bed you could bounce coins off if you were the kind of person who tested domestic surfaces for discipline. Books on pigment and ecclesiastical art and a pamphlet from a group that called themselves Restorers as if the word needed iron legs. That last thing slotted something in her. Hate organizes itself when the weather is right. It puts on old clothes and calls it tradition. The techs found the laptop where they always do, tucked under a shelf with a cloth over it as if modesty could keep law away. In his browser sat rooms in which men with small names wrote big sentences about purity and what parades had stolen. No slurs. They disdained the men outside the station who shouted because shouting lowers the tone. They preferred their violence in diacritical marks and assertions arranged like fences.

“Do we have a network to tend to,” Lindsey asked later, when the first sweep of screenshots had been captured and given the right tags, and the analyst with the neat ponytail had lifted her head and said, “this is both nothing and something,” which was how new fronts often began.

“We have a weather report,” Hinsley said. “Bring in anyone who says they were with him. Anyone who says they almost were. Watch the ones who want to take his place. Watch the ones who want to punish him for not being enough of a monster. There’s always both.”

Out in the waiting room Mr. Ash and Ms. Toller had been replaced by a cardboard box of cinnamon buns with a note that said Thank you in the careful hand of someone who had taken three breaths before writing. The buns were the size of fists and she could smell the spice from the corridor. She took one and bit into it and understood for a pulse that sugar can do the work of blessings. Lindsey leaned against the radiator, which made a hollow clang in protest, and told her the cat had found the fish stamp and was now sleeping on it as if impregnable. “We’re heroes for five minutes,” she said, watching a probationer walk past with the stiffness of someone carrying admiration like a newly named instrument.

“Five minutes is plenty,” Hinsley said. “After that it ossifies into nonsense.”

The parade committee wanted a meeting, which meant a room with plastic chairs and a man called Ivan who handled logistics in a way that made your shoulders obey him. He had a spreadsheet open and he talked about marshals and barriers and where the first aiders stood and how to de-escalate the man who had made himself a one-man editorial. A woman from a charity said very little and took notes and every now and then swallowed like she was taking a pill for pressure. A young organizer in a T-shirt with a design that would get them arrested in three countries asked if they should change the route, and everyone said no so quickly it felt like a shared reflex. Eva was in the corner humming scales under her breath, arms folded in the way that makes you think of sails. She caught Hinsley’s eye and lifted her chin once, a salute from one profession to another. Outside the window a short burst of rain performed itself and then, embarrassed, stopped.

“There’s chatter online,” the ponytail analyst said two hours later, handing over printouts because paper still makes things small enough to think about. “Some Restorers are pleased he’s been caught because he’s given the wrong impression of standards. Some are furious because they think he’s been insufficiently loyal to the cause. Two are saying we don’t need debt now, we need audits. One says the words color and parade in a sentence that makes my shoulders go up.”

“Names?” Lindsey asked, already marking the ones that traced back to actual men who bought loaf bread and paid council tax and told their daughters to Hoover properly.

“Many. A few with real edges,” the analyst said, and she circled three. One had a job in a hardware store that sold primer. The second had left comments on a museum blog about authenticity in maritime paintwork. The third had stood for local council once on a platform of decency that sounded like someone had scraped the pleasure out of every sentence with the straight edge of a palette knife.

Crown set the bail hearing for Friday and the courtroom did its theater with its battered grace. Leonard, in the dock, looked like a man who had been dressed by someone who wanted him not to be a story. His hair was neat and his face had that prison pallor that comes from bright light you cannot control and bad sleep you cannot refuse. He took the oath in a voice that was nearly pleasant. The barrister for defense spoke about lack of prior harm, about community ties, about how art is a misunderstood language and how his client collects rooms the way some men collect bird names. The prosecutor kept things dull in exactly the right way and referred to door codes and camps beds and peppermint oil with the same tone you use for parking tickets. The magistrate looked like a person who has had rain on their collar for twenty years and said remand, and the word had the satisfaction of a stroke done perfectly clean in a pool, no splash.

She met Rune in the evening without actually meeting him. The package with his tea had arrived via a man who looked permanently astonished to be entrusted with other people’s food. Inside was the peppermint kind and the other with the bergamot he insisted she learn to like once every two years so she could refuse with authority. There was a note that said the Swedish for debt and the Swedish for color and a line between them that meant nothing grammatical and everything about railways and ice. She wrote him a message in return that admitted out loud that she had counted in the pool. He replied with the word good and then a photograph of a bakery window where the buns were too golden to be real and the sugar on them made it look as if frost had chosen to come indoors.

Once things seem finished, the city always finds a seam to pick. The receptionist at the front desk—the one who had called her in the night with the pie voice—handed her a letter that had come without a stamp as if delivered by hand and nerve. Inside was a scrap torn from a glossy magazine. Across it someone had written with the kind of pen pressure that makes paper remember the word long after it’s gone: Color is a debt. Pay it at the parade, or we will balance the books for you. The handwriting was not Leonard’s tidy anger. This was loopier, younger in its righteousness, like a person imitating severity without having the chest for it. The analyst traced the paper to an art school prospectus. The thought of an art school folded into this made her stomach feel odd in a way she didn’t trust.

“We increase numbers,” the superintendent said, looking at the note as if it might be persuaded with rank. “We keep eyes up. We make it boring for anyone with a plan. Alva, you’ll run the ground with Ivan. Lindsey, take the marshals. I want to be able to tell the Mayor we can see like gods.”

“No gods,” she said, because she was tired and because the idea offended something in her that liked mortal limits. “Just decent sightlines.”

They added to the plan until the plan had so many lines it looked like a child’s drawing of a spider. In the middle of that, Jamie’s father came to the station alone and waited without picking up a magazine or his phone. He sat as if his body was still trying to learn how to sit after three days of adrenaline. She took him into an interview room that didn’t smell like anyone yet and poured him water into cups that always felt like giving up halfway to tea. He told her about painting signs at the community center for events and how he hated being told he was an artist because the word made him think of people with opinions about chairs. He showed her paint under his nails and said he’d had it on his hoodie the day Jamie went missing because he’d painted a banner that said RIVER FAIR in a font that had made him stupidly proud. He said he had been ashamed that anyone would look at the smear and think what she had thought for a flicker and tell her later she hadn’t because it didn’t matter. She said “you will forgive yourself for nothing and then for everything,” and he laughed a little because the sentence was too heavy and in the wrong room.

On the morning of the parade, there were rainclouds and then there weren’t; the sky did the kind of theatre that makes tourists think we’re dramatic by choice. Barriers went up like square parentheses. People who love flags brought them reverently. People who hate flags stayed home and wrote comments in boxes that made them feel expansive. Eva tuned herself in the mouth of an alley with acoustics she had learned by standing there and listening to her own vowels. The stamp-seller had set up a small stall not to sell, she said, but to be there in case someone needed a fish. She had ink on her fingers again and the cat had forgiven her in increments. Ivan moved his arms and crowds obeyed his punctuation as if instinct. The marshals wore bibs that made them look like teachers about to clap their hands.

Hinsley put herself in the pattern in a way that would look to the untrained eye like loitering. Her cap threw weather at her eyes as if daring her to blink. Lindsey moved with a purpose that would have been menace if she were not smiling intermittently at dogs. The ponytail analyst had given two officers the job of looking like nobody in order to stand near the man from the hardware store and the ex-council candidate and the museum commenter. The superintendent stood by the cameras and performed the difficult trick of being present without becoming theatre. For twenty minutes the joy was so ordinary it made her feel like the job was to shepherd laundry back to lines. Faces were painted with roses and slogans and stars, with dragons that didn’t ask permission before curling around the soft architecture of a cheek.

Then a man stepped up onto a low wall with effort that made him look taller than he was. He had a cap and a jacket and a flyer in his hand with the word debt scrawled across it like an accent. He took a breath to begin the kind of speech that tries to make every color into an invoice. Lindsey reached him in four steps and said something in a tone that allows a person to leave with dignity. He looked at her mouth as if insult and righteousness had become lodged there and then, after the smallest mutiny of muscles, climbed back down because some days people choose to go home and complain to an empty room rather than to a camera. The Restorers who had said the word audit online did not appear except in the way two men’s eyes met over a coffee in a way that said later and then lied about later. For a while it was only color and feet and the old gears of a city turning without squeal.

She saw Rune in the ridiculous way you see people who are not there and are anyway. He would be on an island that was mostly rock and completely history, watching old men in hats discuss the particularities of tiny boats. He would have the tide times folded in his pocket, worn to silk. He would say there is decency in people deciding to walk together even when no money changes hands. He would remind her to breathe out before she breathed in. She did, and the air rewarded her; it felt less like currency and more like a friend’s hand. Eva shifted songs in the middle without anyone but musicians noticing and put a beat into the next the exact rhythm of bicycle wheels on metal. Jamie, shoulder to shoulder with his parents at a corner decided at the last minute, bounced once and looked at his father and then at the grates and then at the wheels, and counted, and the counting had none of the desperation of waiting rooms and all of the abundance of lists made for pleasure. Ms. Toller had her palm over his hair and did not smooth it, which was a victory almost as big as the other one.

After, when the route had been walked and the marshals had unhooked their lanyards as if undoing a secret code and the city had gone back to pretending it was not built for this, the superintendent shook her hand on a doorstep that had seen a century of police shoes. “They’ll call it a triumph,” he said, as if gently deflating the balloon before it could pop.

“They can call it whatever,” she said, and felt the small ribbon of relief curl in her belly, less like steel and more like ribbon this time. “We made it through a day without someone paying in a coin we couldn’t accept.”

Upstairs, on the pinboard, someone had written in a corner, small as if it were a private note that had wandered into public: Color is not a debt, it is a dividend. The handwriting was the ponytail analyst’s, the careful roundness of person who had learned early to make their letters behave. She left it there because sometimes slogans save you from the kind of sentence you write when you’re trying too hard. On her desk was a postcard from a volunteer at the maritime museum with a picture of a ship’s prow painted so many times the under-colors had become a story. On the back: We’ll put better locks. We’ll leave a window for north light because boats deserve to be seen properly when they’re being made decent. She smiled at the contradiction and allowed herself to like it.

There were new files stacked at Control and somebody had left a piece of cake in the break room that was definitely not from a bakery she trusted. Lindsey leaned in and said “a lad at the tech unit says there’s a thread on Restorers where someone is mourning the loss of a good brush. He means Leonard. They’re already turning him into a tool they misused. He’ll hate that more than anything.”

“He’ll pretend not to,” she said, and thought of him in the cell thinking sentences about neatness. She thought of a man who wanted to be a standard and was going to be a cautionary tale instead. She thought about the thin hope that what had happened in a north-light room would make someone somewhere stop their hand halfway to a keyboard. Thin hopes are diet for a profession like hers. They keep you upright without making you arrogant.

In the late afternoon she walked to the river because it had become habit again and habit is architecture when your head feels like a tent in wind. She stood on the bridge and counted without looking at her watch and breathed the air in which a million small particles of city swam. The water made the same sound it always made and also a new one, because sound changes when you give it a boy’s name and hand it back. The gulls swore and a bus rattled and somewhere a child laughed with that precise glee children find when a dog decides to roll in something it should not. On the railing someone had chalked a little dragon, this one with a heart for an eye that was different from the fish’s, and next to it had written, in printing too careful to be an adult’s, THANK YOU POLICE LADY EVEN THOUGH YOU DON’T LIKE PIE. She put her fingers on the cold metal and felt the city sidle a little closer, embarrassed by its own affection.

At home, the orchids forgave her again by not dying. She put Rune’s tea on and this time drank it and let the peppermint sit in the back of her throat and make the air compulsory. She took the magnet fish off the fridge and put it on her noticeboard by the dragon because sometimes you have to make silly talismans formal. She wrote a note to herself in the neatness she reserved for maps: blow out, count, turn, push. It was about swimming. It was also about everything else. Then she let the day leave her body the way steam leaves a pool and climbed into a sleep that did not rehearse anything, not court, not pie, not debt, not windows. Somewhere in the city a man told a room full of people in a forum that the day had been a disgrace, that decency had lost, that color had been vulgar again. Somewhere else a woman gave her girlfriend the last bite of cinnamon bun because love is allocation. On the river, a tide turned, the pipes in the pumping station banged like a good band trying a new song, and the iron remembered hands and then forgot them. There are mornings when the city opens one eye and says not yet, and she had learned to listen. The pool was a rectangle of truce again, steam lifting with courtesy, and her body took its orders without theater. She counted the heartbeats—not out loud, never out loud—let breath leave her like coins down a chute, and turned at fifty as if the tile had petitioned for her hand. There was relief in the old arithmetic. On the fourth length she could feel the list that the day would insist on presenting itself to her—Crown conference, parade debrief, a message from Rune that would likely arrive as a photograph of light pretending to be solid on water—and she set each item in its lane as if they might collide unless she kept watch.

At the station a parcel sat atop her in-tray addressed in a hand that tried on capitals and gave up half way. Inside was a drawing of a dragon with a fish for an eye and the correct number of toes, which was to say too many. Jamie had written, laboring over each bar of the letters, Thank you. The dragon’s fire was not red but green and the fish-eye looked off to the left as if it had noticed something adults had not. She put it on the board near the ponytail analyst’s note about dividends and pretended not to see how everyone’s faces reset when they caught sight of it. The superintendent did what all men who depend upon surfaces do when confronted with sincerity; he adjusted a cuff, said “nice,” and backed away before his mouth betrayed him.

“Press want human,” Lindsey said, leaning into the room as if her body had been invented for thresholds. “Specifically you. Specifically your hair wet from the pool.”

“Press can have paperwork,” she said, and the fax machine immediately made a noise like a hound trying to swallow a harmonica. There were formalities to tend; the bail hearing had ended with the right word, remand, and a handful of men on a forum nobody admitted to reading were using cathode-tube language about martyrs and standards and how debt would be audited. The analyst printed it and handed it round as if passing scones. In among the exclamation points and pious italics, a new phrase had sprouted. Audits now. It had the clipped energy of youth and the sloppiness of imitation.

They did not have to wait long for a scuff of consequence. Around lunchtime, a call from a nursery school whose wall had been turned into a mural by the parents last summer—a riot of jellyfish and wheelbarrows and a boat with a beard—came in with the sting on its own tail. Sometime in the night someone had climbed the low fence, walked past the little plastic bikes like a giant being careful with a miniature city, and laid a wide strip of lead white across the faces in the mural. All the smiling children painted by patient mothers now had blank eyes. Underneath, in chalk that was not the children’s stuff but the dense kind, someone had written AUDIT COMPLETE, and taped above it a half-washed pie tin with a sprig of mint tucked into its edge. Peppermint and linseed hung on the air like arguments.

“He can’t have done it,” Lindsey said in the car, unnecessary as weather. “He’s been counting tile in a remand cell.” She took a corner with a neatness that would have made their driving instructor weep and put a hand out on the dash in a belated apology to physics.

“He taught the city a phrase and someone is trying it on,” Hinsley said, watching the houses go by in their small, repeating bravery. “That’s worse. The grammar will lack his tidy sentences. It will be lazy with itself. It will be eager.”

The nursery smelled of rice crackers and paint, the particular civilizing scent of places that ask children to be kind to objects. The fence had been slid aside with care. The mural looked like a ritual interrupted; white like a sheet over something you’d rather not see, the chalk instructions below it in a hand that had not yet learned the pleasure of pressing too hard. Eva was there—because of course she was—smoothing a child’s hair with the way some people smooth their own, the self-soothing redirected. “I could sing paint back on,” she told the headteacher in a tone that made the hyperbole join the budget. “But maybe we paint over the white with every parent’s hand. We make a second skin.”

“Who saw,” Hinsley asked soft, as if a loud question might break the little chairs. A neighbor had seen a hooded figure move on the fence with that particular caution that makes youth universal. The hood had a logo: a lighthouse, crudely printed.

“The lighthouse guy from the fair?” Lindsey muttered, and immediately shook her head at her own neatness. “No. We’ve been collecting lighthouses like children collect badges.”

They bagged the tin and the chalk, they dealt in sympathies and in promised cleanup crews, and outside the gate the air tasted of sugar. A boy with both knees scabbed and an expression of concentrated mercy said, “the eyes are too white, I don’t like it,” and looked at Hinsley as if she had made eyes and could be petitioned to remake them right. “We’ll change them,” she said, and his shoulders did a small drop that looked like a ribbon untying.

The peppermint had a provenance. It led them not to a hardware store but to one of those little places full of glass bottles with old-fashioned labels: oil of oregano, elderflower cordial, miracle this and memory that. A woman with hair that tried to be rolled up but refused admitted she had sold a quantity of peppermint oil on Thursday to a young man who had asked for two more and then changed his mind with elaborate courtesy. “He called me ‘ma’am,’ and if there is a way to make me feel like furniture that’s it,” she said, half-appalled and half-pleased. “He had paint on his nails but just a dot on each. Like he’d tested a color and not committed.”

They took her memory like something breakable and put it next to Jasko’s ledger, which had a scrawl for rabbit-skin glue sold to a student who had asked how long you had to soak it before you could pretend you were not using an animal. “E. Vane,” the name read, which was either a badge of carelessness or a poor man’s alias. The analyst traced an email on the art school’s mailing list with the same approximation. Vane had signed up for a room with north light in the old courthouse the school used for the classes nobody funded properly. He’d asked if he could bring his own primer, he’d asked if anyone minded the smell of oil, he’d asked a question about ethics with a performative flourish. The head of school, a woman who wore dresses cut out of the concept of ironed, told them Vane was “earnest” in the way teachers use when they mean please don’t let this become an anecdote later.

The old courthouse had windows as tall as a confession. Dust had decided to live here and made it personal. They stood in the room labelled Print and watched a young man argue with a press that had survived three regimes of fashion. His hair lay in a tidy that had cost thought. His hands were trembling inside his attempt at composure; his fingertips had garden dirt of ultramarine and cadmium red caught beneath them in crescents. His rucksack had on its side a stitched patch of a lighthouse. “Elliot Vane?” Lindsey asked, opening with the gentlest possible complaint pronunciation can become. He nodded and looked at both of them as if he were trying to rank them by the kindness of their collars.

“You’re selling peppermint oil in paintings,” she said, which was not a question and not an accusation and something in the way she allowed his denial an easy perch made him relax a fraction. “I don’t paint,” he said automatically, and then smiled at the lie’s own silliness. “I mean, of course I paint. But mostly I print. Woodcuts. Linocuts. You can wipe oil off lino forever and it keeps remembering it.”

“Were you at the nursery last night,” Hinsley asked, and watched the shadow of the answer pass across his face. He wanted to be someone already loved by a narrative; caught and redeemed or caught and admired for his noble stand. “I was at home,” he said, only not to be coy but to see how it felt in his mouth. “I read posts,” he added, and it was the first truth he’d offered them.

“The Restorers,” Lindsey said, carefully not rolling her eyes into an expression that would make him decide she couldn’t be a fair witness. “The men who like their purity hygienic.”

“They like their standards,” he corrected, and then colored as he heard himself in their hands. “They want—” He stopped because there is a point in a conversation with the police where you either confess to ideology or to action, and he was too fond of the idea that he was building a self to settle for being a set of verbs. “I liked the way Leonard talked about north light,” he said, low, as if admitting tenderness. “He makes sense about light. About not letting things get muddled by sunshine. I loathe parades. They make me feel like the wrong person in my own body.”

“Do they make you paint over children’s faces,” Hinsley asked, and he flinched, which disappointed him in himself. He wanted his convictions to be immune to the reality of small hands and jellyfish. “I don’t harm,” he said earnestly, borrowing someone else’s innocence. “I correct.”

She thought of the pie tins and the peppermint oil, of chalk on brick and violet on a child’s cheek. He would almost certainly become something else if left to his own devices; perhaps a teacher who took the joy out of color by grading it too neatly, perhaps a man who learned to hold a lover’s hand without thinking of contagion. He was still turnable. He was also not innocent. His bag smelled like a toothpaste aisle. When asked about the lighthouse, he said “I like the shape,” and only afterward realized that shapes have a history in this city, that lighthouses meant something to a man with a puppet and to a boy who had sat on a camp bed and believed someone’s line about dragons.

They brought him in not in cuffs but in awkwardness. He sat in Interview Two and drank water as if it asked something of him. He conceded that he posted as SecondBrush. He conceded that he’d copied Leonard’s words into a notebook because the neatness of the hand had felt like somebody setting a table with knives in the right order. He conceded that he was in the pumping station the week before because he liked how the iron sang under his feet, and he did not know the word alibi so he said route and told it to them like a pilgrim listing saints.

“We’re looking for you because of a wall,” she told him, and put the photographs down where he could either look or not. He looked. He looked away. “That’s not an audit,” he said weakly, and then recovered himself into enthusiasm the way boys do when they are afraid their teacher will be disappointed. “There’s a theory,” he said, pulling his hands off the table as if they might show too much, “about how modern color is noisy. We need quiet. Like winter light. You’re from Sweden,” he added suddenly, as if it conferred upon her the patent for snow.

“I am from everywhere my mother loved,” she said, because it was the only answer that did not let him build a box around her and set her where he needed. He blushed at the intimacy of having guessed at a geography and went sullen for a moment with the shame of being too open.

They let him talk and collected the phrases because phrases are handles you can pick men up by later. He said “debt,” and then, when Lindsey looked bored on purpose, he tried out “audit” in its careful syllables, watched it do no magic at all, and put it away. He admitted to the lighthouse patch being handed out at a meeting of “boys who like to build things,” a place that called itself a workshop and had one drill and ten opinions. He had not, he insisted, met Leonard in person. He had sent letters to a PO Box that belonged to a man who had three surnames and a photograph with a spaniel. He had received nothing back but he had written his handwriting into neatness anyway, to be ready.

“We have a vandalism,” she said, and she watched him decide whether to claim it for noble reasons or deny it to preserve some future in an art room. He took the middle path, which is to say he could not yet bear a consequence. “I walked past,” he said in a voice like paper. “It made my chest feel right. I smelled mint. I did not put the white. I don’t buy lead,” he added, and there was relief in the mitigation, as if being a modern bigot were somehow cleaner.

Afterward, in the corridor, Lindsey did the patient hands-out gesture that has saved as many as any statute. “He’s a child with a vocabulary,” she said, not as comfort. “He’s a bridge. There’ll be a man with a job hiding behind him.”

“Hardware store,” the analyst said, popping up like a well-timed buoy. “Our friend at Kemp & Kerr on the High Road—Callum Dyer—is in three of the Restorers chats and uses an account that also talks about varnish on the museum blog. He’s been in the pump annex as a volunteer. He orders primer for the paint-the-town committee. He keeps his receipts tidy. His boss is Kerr, who stood for councillor once and will tell you his middle name if you let him.”

They took Dyer in the way you take a bolt from a machine—with enough care that the whole doesn’t collapse and enough speed that the bolt can’t pretend it isn’t part of a system. He smelled of honest shop and cheap soap and had cheeks that either wanted to be perpetually flushed or had been told to by weather. He said he was tired of color telling him what to think. He said he liked boats but not flags. He said he’d bought peppermint oil for a girlfriend who got carsick and had no girlfriend to produce and reddened in the ears when he realized he had made himself audible. When shown the nursery wall he went dead-eyed for a second that told her he had a photograph of it taken at night on his phone, and then said of course children’s things are lovely because your body cannot help itself sometimes.

Back in the interview, Leonard listened with interest when she said the words SecondBrush and Callum. He had been given permission by his barrister to say nothing and permission by his vanity to say many things. “The young are impetuous in their obedience,” he said, hands steepled in a way you’d do if you wanted to stab a cloud. “They never sand their edges. They bake pies with poor pastry.” The last word had weight in it that made her want to throw the table. He smiled faintly. “Your parade was vulgar,” he added, as if inserting footnotes into her diary. “You will let it be vulgar again and again because you are allergic to responsibility.”

“Responsibility is specific,” she said, polite to his definitions. “You make it abstract to save your soul and your skin. We have a boy who will count the names on boats in spite of you. We have a wall that will be repainted by sticky hands. We have a river. It mistakes itself for no man’s line.”

He closed his eyes for a moment like a painter considering a second layer. It was something like prayer and something like self-sedation. When he opened them there was—instead of revelation—age. He looked his smallness straight on for a second, and then returned to his tidy bench inside. “Your metaphors will tire you,” he said, as if concerned for her calves. “My sentences rest.”

Rune, when he called, did not unduly perform worry. He sent a photograph of the Baltic having a conversation with the sky about slate and then said, “I saw a demonstration on Skeppsbron,” as if telling her about the weather. “Men marched with flags, and women did too, and one of the old men from the swimming club held his banner as if it were a very good fish he was taking home to fry. There were boys who shouted and other boys who addressed each other as if they were old captains. In Swedish, color is also guilt if you tilt the word the right way,” he added, with the schoolteacher’s delight at homonyms. “Skuld. We make a mistake of it. We attach guilt to debt and debt to color and think we have told a truth. Language is a dangerous friend.”

“I have a boy who drew me a dragon,” she said, and it felt like offering him the exact right piece of cake across a kitchen table, the corner with the most icing. “He made the eye a fish.”

“Wise child,” Rune said. “Dragons that remember rivers cause less trouble.” He paused and then did the thing he rarely did, which was ask for her. “Come for a weekend,” he said, as if proposing brushing their teeth at the same sink. “Before the river here freezes you should put your hands back into this one and say hello to your smaller ghosts.”

She didn’t answer right away because refusal sometimes frightens off acceptance if you give it room. “After Crown,” she said finally, and he took her promise without turning it into a religious object.

At Kemp & Kerr, the boss Kerr had an old politician’s face that could remember smiles even when it did not deploy them. He had the habit of standing with his weight on one hip that made cheap suits look like repentance. He had nothing to do with boys online, he said with the practiced hover of someone who has been near badness and kept his cuffs clean, but he knew how much primer the parade used and what time the annex closed because he had helped out his mate long before any of these new committees had decided they invented community. He had a son with a stammer and a ledger with perfect columns. “You tell those Restorer lads,” he said, eyes on the counter he wiped when anxious, “that this city belongs to people who queue,” and began to talk about respect as if it had a unit of measure you could write on a tin.

The parade committee came back, not for apologies but for a kind of debriefing therapy. Their treasurer cried because the floats had cost so much time and nobody had died. Eva brought biscuits and sang without the singing part, the voice doing its work as tone alone. The stamp-seller, who had reclaimed the right to be called Mara rather than “that poor woman,” inked a tiny fish on the inside of her wrist as if to remind herself of both fragility and buoyancy. A teenage boy came with a broken lighthouse patch and put it on the table and said, in a voice he was trying to make deep, that he didn’t want to belong to any club that dressed hatred as something old and therefore polite. Ivan handed him a safety pin with the solemnity of a knighting.

They charged Elliot with criminal damage because the chalk was his and the white was not, and they warned him about entering forums with boys who talk about standards when they mean power. He cried and then was embarrassed to be seen crying and tried to turn it into anger because that direction felt more masculine. He asked if Leonard would be moved to a nicer cell because he didn’t like damp, and Lindsey said “no cell is nice,” with a tiredness that had always been truth. Elliot’s mother came, worn from shift, and looked at her son like she could still locate the baby in the bones and wasn’t sure if it helped. She thanked them too many times with a civility that had cost her pride money, and in the corridor she and Hinsley stood like two opposite sides of a bridge and shared the view.

In the late light, under a sky the color of a bruise deciding to heal, they went back to the pumping station because she could not leave the iron to its memory without supervisory kindness. She put her hand on the panel that swung and spoke to the hinge in her head like you speak to a horse. The dog trotted over and did that dog thing of inventing a game out of presence. On the catwalk above, a bike went across and made the hum that Jamie liked. She thought of the way he had counted after, not in fear but in pleasure. She thought of the morning he would choose a different shirt and nobody would tell him his dinosaur had been the wrong dragon. The river lifted as if inhaling and then set itself calmly again, a chest that had decided on a rhythm sane enough for living.

The crime scene techs found on a later afternoon a stash hidden behind a panel in the annex that belonged not to Leonard but to the idea of him; flags folded with primness, notes with bullet points about what would and would not be allowed when they took the city back from its color. They found a photograph of a pie on a plate with a fork laid to the right as if Sunday had been given a costume. They found a list of shopkeepers who keep the old receipts—names underlined in an admiration that felt like possession. There were two names on the list already in custody and a third—M. Pike—who had left comments about the authentic tint of nineteenth-century hulls and the improper hue of modern parades. They took him from his computer softly, in socks, and he tried to bore them into leaving with an essay about paint in the time of arctic expeditions, which made the ponytail analyst unexpectedly happy because at last, a man who went on about boats, she said, without realizing the infidelity to the case.

Majors gave way to minors; that is the shape of actual policing. After the parades and the pies comes the theft of a charity box that turns out to be a boy with a bruise and a mother with a bruise and a father with a bruise inside where there’s no statute. After the forum captured and the lighthouses confiscated comes a woman who has been followed home from a bus stop three nights in a row by a fear with the wrong shoes on. There is reminder, because the work does not care for your through-lines. On the board, the dragon and the dividend note stayed pinned in the corner like the friend who keeps the chair next to them open in case you need to sit.

At night, she sat at her table at home and wrote Rune’s name on a piece of paper and put it where she would see it, like a charm you can name and therefore make ridiculous and therefore powerful. The orchids picked up light like older ladies pick up gossip. She drank his tea, peppermint cutting through the day’s palate, and read the postcard he had sent before his call, the one with the lighthouse peeling and the sky demonstrating three kinds of gray. On the back, he had written Färgskuld in his precise hand and then drawn a shaky line between the words and then, as if ashamed of earnestness, a little fish, because he had learned what she kept.

In the morning she went to the pool and there was a boy in the next lane counting under his breath, practising not drowning as children do in every country. She did not think of debt or parades. She did not think of lighthouses or pie tins or lead. She thought of tile and of the exact feel of three thousand meters in the bones. She swam until her shoulders agreed they belonged to her again. When she left, the air smelled of rain deciding, a gull announced a calamity in a language only other gulls recognize, and the city made its lists, kind and cruel and ordinary. The river had relented to an ordinary color, less like an argument and more like a mood that didn’t need announcing. After the parade, the city seemed to speak a little quieter, as if hoarseness had made it modest. In the station, the board had been sheared of its worst: Leonard’s name was still the center pole, but the nets hanging from it now were tidy lists of court dates, evidential chains with their links numbered and humming with bureaucracy. The ponytail analyst had pinned a printout of the forum in the corner with a bright dot next to the posts that said Audit Now, as if labeling could make zeal choose a different verb. A stack of statements had acquired the density of bread left to go stale. Hinsley stood with a coffee that would not help and read the top page of a CPS memo with the peculiar concentration you save for things that pretend to be dull and will, if you do not watch, blindside you with a requirement you cannot meet.

She went down to the river before the meeting with Crown because the river had become part of her routine again and she was careful with routines now. Eva had set herself at her usual spot near the railings, tying a scarf as if preparing herself to sing were a job for fingers and knots as much as lungs. She was not singing yet. She was choosing keys by whistling shyly and testing the acoustics on a long held vowel until it melted away into motor noise and gull complaint. “You look like you slept for half of a night,” Eva said, which in her grammar was a blessing. “The boy brought me his dragon at the market and explained why fish eyes are clever. He will be insufferable about being clever for a week, and then he will be ordinary again, and that will be the miracle.”

“I like a miracle that pays in ordinaries,” Hinsley said. “Are your dates set for the boat songs next month.”

“I will sing until my voice is embarrassed,” Eva said. “They brought me a new microphone. It makes me sound like someone other people have known longer.” She smoothed her hair and looked out across the water as if it were a score. “They sent me two notes,” she added, dropping it into the air as if confessions should travel at shoulder height. “One said sing something clean. One said clean something with singing. Boys playing at being old men.”

“Keep the notes,” Hinsley said. “Sometimes paper confesses more than the hand that wrote it thinks it does.”

Crown’s chair pinched the backs of knees viciously in the way that expensive chairs never do. The barrister had the face of a man who has learned to enjoy the shape of constraints. He set out his staging like a cook talking about stock—care for bones, disdain for extra. “We will not make him a sermon,” he said, and put his hands flat on the table like a person reminding a room to attend to surface. “We will not talk about tides of hatred or cultural rot. We will treat him like a man who took something he had no right to. We will treat his lectures the way we treat fumes. Mention, ventilate, then leave to disperse.”

“He is writing,” the CPS caseworker added, with the complicated gleam of a person torn between the usefulness of a letter and the unpleasantness of being the sort of person who hopes for one. “He likes to copy out pigment histories. He has drafted you something, Inspector.”

She read it later, back in the ugly light of her office, with a pencil in hand so her brain could have the satisfaction of making marks on a man’s sentences. It was very tidy. He had drawn boxes and arrows as if presenting a thought experiment. He made suggestions about how to light the interview room so that north might fall into it, which was almost funny. He used the word correction nine times and debt five and hope once, which made her mouth make the shape of a laugh even though she didn’t let the sound come. He signed using the long version of his name, Leonard, a formality chosen like a collar. She underlined three phrases not because they might be evidence but because they told the shape of his self. I do not injure. I order. You flood. She folded it and put it into a folder, and then into a drawer, not because things were safer in drawers but because the act of using a drawer is sometimes the only way to tell your body that you have taken control of something.

In the afternoon, a smell came to them before the call: that thin, sweet, worrying edge of oil on hot air. Fire does not always announce itself by roaring. Sometimes it lets the nose and the back of the throat be the heralds. The call was from a caretaker with a voice turned small by smoke. An arts workshop in an old Sunday school had burned in a way that was both contained and dangerous; rags left crumpled in a corner under a window had become a sermon about oxidation and time. The first officer on scene did not say arson, which pleased her; he said somebody was very careless with old gods and oils.

The building was a lesson in handsome economies: brick that had been painted white too many times, ceilings high enough to make watchers of anyone who entered, north windows square as foreheads. The black patch on the floor near a table had a tidy outline; the flames had not liked moving past a certain invisible border, and for once she was grateful to the stinginess of air. There were linseed stains on the table edge where someone had been generous with a bottle, and then the pattern that makes fire investigators grimace: rags, wadded not laid flat, left in a fellowship of heat and ignorance to conspire. The caretaker, a woman with hands that made you think of knitting and scaffolding poles, said she had left the lights off, as usual, when she locked up, and when she came in this morning for the WI quilting group she had found this ruin and her throat had announced it before her eyes could.

“We didn’t have much that would have made a proper blaze,” the caretaker said, showing them the room next door where plaster dust had settled into the corners like flour. “But men came last night to glue canvas. Old methods. Rabbit skin, I think. They said they knew what they were doing. One of them had very clean fingernails for a painter.”

“Names,” Lindsey said, without making the word into a demand, and received a shrug made of memory and kindness. A first name, maybe Vince, maybe Vane, had been written in a pencil that had been sharpened within an inch of its life and torn through two of the eight lines on a sign-in sheet. There had been talk about standards that made the caretaker’s hands make a shape, the shape of someone setting down a bowl with too much care and then leaving the room. “They said the new paints are lies,” she said, with the patient contempt of women who have heard more than one man explain chemistry to them as if invention had been pending their moral approval.

At the corner under the window someone had chalked a small arrow on the skirting. It pointed not at the rags but at the empty space above, where light fell neat and honest. Under the arrow someone had written two words with a grip that tried to write in copperplate and succeeded only in looking tentative. Let in. It was not Leonard’s tidy hand. It had the trace of a boy copying the flourishes off a poster. The bottles on the sill, three of them, had from the smell been peppermint’s cousins—wintergreen, a little eucalyptus—and one was peppermint proper, bought from the same symptoms-and-cures place as the nursery’s tin of mint. The woman in that shop knew the peppermint had gone to a young man with the lighthouse patch and a jacket with elbows worried by a pair of careful hands. His name on her receipt had been Eli V., and he had given her a look of gratitude for seeing him as initials that made the analyst mutter a sentence about boys who like to be subsections.

They found Elliot in the print room again, trying to make the press recognize him as someone it could trust. He owned the exhaustion around his eyes as if he had borrowed it gratefully. When faced with photographs of the scorch and the rag bloom, he didn’t feign surprise—he wouldn’t dare now. He looked at the image like a child looks at a tipped glass, seeing both accident and his own hand. “You can’t even,” he said, and stopped, because he did not know the end of his sentence. “Linseed takes air and returns heat,” he said finally, with the careful recitation of a man who had read the right sentence and liked its neatness. “You don’t pile the rags. You put them in water or you lay them flat.” He had done neither. His face said it and then flushed with the knowledge that even if he had not piled them, someone he admired had, and now admiration felt like an accomplice again.

“Who were the men,” Hinsley asked, and he picked at the skin near his thumbnail, the primitive boyhood tic of making pain on purpose while deciding whether to betray a hero. “Callum brought me,” he said, after two breaths and a swallow. “He knows rooms with north light. There was a man who joked about auditors and then spent twenty minutes folding the brown paper you wrap finished canvases in and made it the neatest thing in the room. He had a cap and no patch. He used a different name to everyone else’s mouth every time someone asked him for it.”

The caps. The patches. The lighthouses. Boys in workshops where drills were ornaments and purity had a WhatsApp thread. The hardware store had receipts for boiled linseed that would make someone’s insurer have a day. The caretaker remembered a hand lingering on a window latch as if latches were poetry. The ponies in the analyst’s graphs performed their square dance of digital connections with cheerful surrender. The thread had stripped into rope. They pulled on it and felt it go taut. It did not yet come away in their hands.

Rune called as she was walking across the bridge, not to discuss oils or latches but to send her weather in a photograph so precisely gray you could taste iron filings if you let your tongue imagine. After she thanked the sky, he told her, with the casual air of a man who cannot help turning the day into a lesson, that he had spent a serious apprenticeship once learning about rags. “The boatyard where I was young used to keep a bucket on each bench,” he said, his voice dropping into that fondness he reserved for practicalities. “Not for mess. For soaking cloth that had oil in it. There was a boy burned to the wrists because he thought air was for men, not cotton. He learned. I learned. The bucket had a lid. We had a man with a whistle who would blow it if he saw any rag left proud of its brethren. Sometimes the whistle saved us. Sometimes older men saved us. We owe older men,” he added, and in his grammar of debt that was grace, not a ledger.

“Older men and a bucket,” she said, and he laughed in agreement, a bright short sound like the sun choosing to show itself between tasks. He invited her then, not officially, but in the tone he used for imperative kindness. “Come on Saturday,” he said, as if trains could be conjured by suggestion. “Bring me your shoulders. I will not make hot drinks at an inadequate speed and ask you to do nothing. We will look at a window and decide what north is doing. We will name boats we do not own.”

She shouldn’t have been able to. There were debriefs and a Dyer and a Vane and a boy with worker’s soap under his nails and a man awaiting trial and rags petitioning to kill rooms. But the aftershocks had softened into lists now; there were men who liked forums and there were rooms with windows and she could leave this for two days without the river changing its course out of spite. She booked a flight with the mild guilt of someone who is cheating on the weather. On Friday morning she put the orchids into the sink and told them not to dramatize the watering while she was away. She wrote a note for Lindsey that contained only three dangerous nouns. Dyer. Annex. Nursery. The fourth was cake, which in their system meant eat something and do not be a fool. Lindsey hugged it against her chest like a shield and made a face at her as if to say don’t meet an old cities’ ghosts and marry them.

Stockholm received her with its particular curriculum of light. October there did not sulk. It determined. Rune’s flat had changed very little in the years since she had last sat at his small kitchen table, except the magnet on his fridge was a piece of iron with a story and not a comedy fish, and the postcard he had stuck above the kettle was one she had sent him of the river in her own city, as if geography were a courtesy you could return. He made buns to the exacting rhythm she remembered—measure, of course, but measured with the grace of someone who sees flour as topography. He put on coffee as if coffee were a translation that demanded program notes. After she slept for an hour in a room with a window that observed birches, he took her down to the water.

The men at the Baltic swam less like athletes and more like penance. He had not exaggerated when he wrote that the old ones swam naked as reasons; it was not erotic, not comedy, not political. It was a way of taking inventory in weather. She did not go in; she only watched Rune take the cold and turn it into the shape of himself in the water, a man who had chosen a new wife and a stepdaughter with an accent and a line in her brow that said she would always mistrust furniture. He came out rosy and outrageous and alive and told her to stop being a coward, with the delicacy of a man who had learned when to be rude in service of care. She put her hands in up to the wrist and called it enough. He kissed her hair with the legitimacy that comes with repetition.

On the ferry to the island where he liked to look at lighthouses, he practiced saying guilt and debt and color and claimed there was a folktale about a man who owed the sea three hairs from his head every year or his boat would sink. She offered him a similar English nonsense tale about a man who refused to pay a ferryman and was made to carry pebbles instead of coins until his back broke. They agreed in their polyglot way that debt was a poor metaphor for water and an even poorer one for joy. He said “your parade looked brave,” without asking her to explain how a day of girls with faces painted into tigers could scare a man like Leonard. She said “your buns are too sweet,” without admitting she had stood in her kitchen in England with his tea and his magnet and practiced being alive around suddenly finished stories.

On Sunday he taught her the whistle of the boatyard, which was low and practical; he put two fingers between his teeth and made the sound of men being saved from their own resolve. She put two fingers between hers and could only make air. “You puff like a polite horse,” he said, and clapped his hands once when she managed an undignified squeal that made the women by the jetty look over and look away.

The city she returned to was sulking again in damp, which meant it was relieved to see her because it could be rude without consequences. On her desk was a note from Lindsey with a drawing of a tent with a bat on it that meant someone on nights had found no monsters and had nevertheless told stories. Beneath it, two receipts linked Kemp & Kerr’s ledgers to purchases for the annex—primer, rabbit glue, boiled linseed—delivered to a back door by Dyer’s own hand. Next to that, a scrawl from the analyst in letters squarer than the world deserved: M. Pike’s online name is Heeling, as in boats, as in we get the metaphor. He comments on varnish. He mows an allotment. He is dull in a worrying way.

They brought Dyer in at six on Tuesday morning because men forget to be suspicious at six and because the shop would not yet be open and because sometimes kindness is simply timing. His flat above the store smelled of paint that had been thinned too eagerly and bread gone to sadness. There was a photograph of a dog on the dresser with a ball in its mouth and the date of its death in the frame, the kind of grief that made her want to leave the room so it could be just between dog and man. He talked himself into a myth in the first ten minutes and then out of it in the next five. He had not painted eyes white; he had delivered what men who admired him asked him to deliver and had taken his small fee in the currency of inclusion. He had a threadbare lighthouse patch on a jacket he no longer felt entitled to wear because the boys with better sentences had decided he was more logistics than soul.

“Who told you to put peppermint on it,” Lindsey asked, and he startled because the addition of peppermint to a sentence should not make a person jump and did. “Leonard hates turpentine,” he said, shame warming his ear tips. “He says it smells like negligence. In the third drawer, under a tea towel, a ledger of receipts with notes in a neat hand about who had paid for what and when. It was not a conspiracy that would thrill a parliament. It was simply a system. He had made meetings possible and had liked the way gratitude made him feel like a good man. He had not thought past the end of a night to the morning’s call to a nursery headteacher or a caretaker with a bucket in her hands and smoke making a poem out of her throat.

They did not give Dyer the luxury of martyrdom. They charged him with being a necessary part of other people’s damage and gave his name to papers that would print it in a font that made men like him look more dangerous than they often are. It was not fair, none of it, and it was exactly right; fairness in the aggregate is always a mess for particular births of harm. Elliot watched from his own small seat in an interview room as they told him they’d be charging him for the chalk and the white journey on a wall. “You can still be a teacher of what not to do,” the analyst told him, and he cried again and said he didn’t want to teach, he wanted to print fish and boats like the stamp-seller but with more detail. “Do both,” Lindsey said, and whether it was a mockery or a mercy was for him to find out.

He had come with his father to bring the dragon with the fish eye on thick paper and had also brought, carefully, a second picture on lined exercise book torn out too near the staple.
