She looked at the sketch, and then at him, and then at the river’s map in her head. She took Lindsey without telling the superintendent where her feet were going and went to the pumping station where the iron had been taught to hum. She had thought they had emptied that small cathedral of his excuses. They had not. Taped to the underside of a girder, because even small men can learn from movies, was a memory card inside a plastic bag with a label that read 2/9, which could have been a date or could have been a count in a mind that always wanted to put people in rows. On it were three files: one of flags being pulled down by neat hands in the night as if they were laundry taken in because of weather, one of the annex room arranged into lecture, chairs precisely spaced as if chairs themselves could perform virtue, and one of a slow pan across a boy asleep on a camp bed wearing a dinosaur that a man had decided was the wrong dragon and had been wrong again. It was monstrous that this evidence ensured the trial would have something that would make jurors feel the right outrage. It was also a relief that a man who admired neatness kept copies for himself and did not trust the cloud. She felt the bad satisfaction in her bones and refused to name it more than once.

The rest of the week fell into that familiar cadence that makes work feel like a piece of music in a key you can hold. Statements cleaned themselves into coherence, with the coaxing that officers like her know how to apply without making it look like pressure. The Crown drafted a skeleton argument with a row of bullet points that, if translated into ordinary speech, read like common sense instead of outrage, which is how these things must go to last. The press called the movement Restorers even now, as if agreeing to their chosen name meant conceding some territory in public imagination. Someone graffiti’d over the word in the annexe with a different tag that said Rotters in bubble letters, and she didn’t tell anyone that the shape of the letters gave her more joy than it should have. She went to Kemp & Kerr and bought a brush she didn’t need and paid cash, and watched Kerr count it as if counting money had always been his path to considering himself useful to the world. He did not like what had come out of evenings in rooms with his name on the delivery sheet. He liked even less being made to like and hate at the same time. She saw the conflict bruise his face in a way that made him look a decade younger.

Rune wrote her a postcard that arrived two days after she had stayed at his table, the mail’s sense of theatre always being late. It was a lighthouse painting whose paint had come away in the top quarter to reveal that white is never truly white. On the back he had written, in his neat teacher’s hand, the Swedish for bake and for fuel and for light, and had drawn lines between them like a child making constellations. He had added in the corner the word for rag and three exclamation marks, because some warnings deserve punctuation.

They had one more incident before the court took hold of the story and made it theirs. A pub on the corner of a quieter street that had chosen to call itself safe for people who liked people was found in the morning with its chalkboard wiped blank and the words Audit This written on it in the careful childish hand of someone aping severity. There was no paint, no peppermint, no lead. There was a little pile of lighthouse patches on the doorstep like a surrender ceremony performed by someone who could not commit to an actual surrender because the drama would be missed. Ivan walked past and picked one up, stuck it on his own jacket, and carried it into the station where he left it on her desk with the affect of a man returning a live grenade that turned out to be a toy. “Use it for evidence,” he said, and then crushed his hand over his forehead in a gesture that would have been theatrical if it were not a man who had spent a week telling others where to stand finally admitting he had a pain.

The magistrate and then a judge would smooth the narrative into what the law can carry. Jurors would be asked to imagine north light and rooms with rags and peppermint oil on pies as if any of that had to do with guilt. The parade committee would become a paragraph. The boy’s dinosaur would be a line asked to perform too much work in a room that does not like metaphor. They would make it work anyway because the Crown could slice and place and label for an audience who will do its duty better if it has small furniture to arrange in its mind. Hendry, the prosecutor, practiced his questions in a voice like gravel smoothed in a pocket over years. “Why the peppermint, Mr Briggs,” he would say, not interested in the answer for curiosity’s sake but because juries like to be told a little motif that they can hum in the jury room while someone remembers a law from the television and gets it slightly wrong. She sat with him and said the word nicely, the word reluctantly, the word tidy, and he smiled in the way barristers smile when they think they might be able to produce relief from logic.

On a Thursday morning, before all that theatre could begin, she went back to the pool because she was beginning to understand that there were weeks when the lane was as necessary as warrants and statements and receipts. She did the ritual without thinking and then realized that not thinking was the ritual, that counting is a device you use to prevent yourself from narrating, and that not narrating is sometimes the only kindness you can do for your head when the head has watched men try to make their outing into prose. The lifeguard had a new paperback and her face had lost its hostility, perhaps because she had watched the morning news and recognized someone’s shoulders, perhaps because she had had a good breakfast. She put fifty on fifty and then put another fifty on top of that and finished with the particular fatigue that shares a border with satisfaction. On her way out, her phone vibrated like a small fish and it was Rune, sending the photograph he had promised of the dregs of coffee in a mug turned on its side so she could see rings that looked a little like isobars. “I think of you in rings,” he wrote. “I know this is not romantic. It is a navigational compliment.”

She took that into the day like a small heat. Crown would ask her to be tidy and someone’s mother would ask her to be human and the superintendent would ask her to be emblematic and Lindsey would ask her to be hungry and the analyst would ask her to be curious and the man in the hardware store would ask her to be fair and the boy would ask her to be reasonable about dragons. She could be some of those at once and not all. That was the adult arithmetic. She made her lists, the city made its, and between them there was a space where mistakes could become lessons and then, if you were very lucky and very stubborn, become routines. She pinned Jamie’s dragon next to the lighthouse patch and let them look at each other as if the conversation could continue without her.

On Sunday evening, when the air had decided not to rain out of sheer boredom, she met Eva near the railings again. The singer had not learned to sing paint back on brick, but she had collected parents and brushes and together they had made the white into a second skin painted by dozens of hands, and there is something about dozens of hands that makes neatness nervous. The jellyfish were more determined, the wheelbarrow had acquired a little flag with colors that would irritate the men who wanted to correct joy, and above the bearded boat someone had written, in a hand that had taken itself seriously and then not, LETTING IN, not as order but as blessing. Eva looked at it with a property owner’s pride. “Sometimes repetition is the point,” she said. “We will repaint again when they tire and we will tire less quickly, because we get to choose our exhausting.”

Hinsley put her fingers on the cold railing and listened for the iron’s modest song. The river was not a ledger. It did not accept payments or hand you change. It told you what had fallen into it and what it intended to carry and what it would give back when your back was turned because some surprises only succeed when you’re not watching. She thought of Leonard in his cell trying to find north by the light of a strip that hummed a wrong note. She thought of Elliot trying to learn shame without making himself an author of it beyond necessity. She thought of Callum making deliveries for boys with better words and worse courage, and of his dog whose photo made him human without absolving anything. She thought of Rune’s whistle and of older men who saved younger ones with the simple violence of sound. She thought of a boy who would wear a different shirt soon and whose father would never again think a smear of paint on a hoodie meant jeopardy. She thought of being allowed to call herself by two names and being a person for whom both were true. She had learned, perhaps, to breathe in water that was not hers and to make it hers by repetition.

On Monday, court would begin to do what court does, which is to try to make stories hold still long enough for twelve people and a man in a robe to agree what happened. She would sit in a witness box and say sentences in a careful order and make her mouth do stone work. Later in a different time she would get on a flight to Stockholm for two days and call it return instead of running. Now, she walked home along streets that were beginning to think about winter in their gutters, passing the fish stamp on Mara’s wrist as she locked up, passing Kemp & Kerr where a man closed a till as if the sound could scare away ideology, passing a boy with a lighthouse patch sewn unpicked from a jacket and repurposed onto a bag where it looked less like allegiance and more like a souvenir from a museum shop. She put her key into the door and thought of tide tables. She counted, because counting made all the rooms in her head come to a productive quiet. Then she went inside and fed the orchids too much water and laughed at herself and wrote on her noticeboard blow out, count, turn, push, and below it, not in the neatness Leonard had wanted of her but in her swimmer’s scrawl, let in.Chapter 10

The river had made itself plain again. After a week of courtroom air—dry, filtered, old carpet and old sentences—it felt almost indecent to be reminded that water has no respect for procedure. It breathed under the bridge with its usual disregard for narrative, lifting and setting like a creature whose only duty was to remain alive. She stood for a minute and let it dictate her first rhythm of the morning. Then she went to the pool and made the same bargain she had made every day of the trial: fifty to stop the mind from rehearsing, fifty to prevent the body from pretending it didn’t need tending, and fifty because repetition is a better friend than hope when a room is going to require your mouth to stay in order.

Court had its own lanes. The usher with the voice like a line drawl kept them in parallel. The judge in his soft, battered authority kept the temperature a precise degree above humiliation. The jurors sat with faces that tried too hard to be neutral and therefore revealed themselves as kindly, impatient, entered into service with a humility that made you want to be good for them. Hendry the prosecutor kept his sentences deliberately smaller than his appetite. The defense counsel—Mr Purcell, a man whose hair had learned to be glossy by being spoken to, not by oil—did his best work when he pretended to be disappointed in the world’s lack of neatness.

The day Hinsley took the stand, the room behaved as it always did when a woman who had found a boy is asked to perform finding for an audience. The sound drew close around her like heavy curtains. She looked at the oath card and thought of Rune with two fingers and a whistle, ridiculous and then necessary, and she spoke the promise evenly, as if reading a departure time off a platform that would not leave without her.

Hendry walked her through the maps of events with the same care he used to walk through a boatyard: avoid the rust, keep your hand off the parts that look recently painted. The white van became a rectangle on a photograph, then a rectangle in a yard, then a set of plates that had held other names before. The annex with its north light became a grid of dates and deliveries. The peppermint oil was made tame on a chain-of-custody form. The memory card made the jurors’ eyes dip and flinch in a human wave, and then the room did the decent thing and returned its attention to the labels and the times. She said the word dragon once and did not say the boy’s name; they had agreed on this, and even if they had not, her body would have refused to say it here. She described the chair central in the annex and kept her voice from describing what it was to see an outline of a child waiting to be turned from charcoal into idea. She told them he had planned, that he had chosen spaces where air was polite and light did not shift, that he had hired cleanliness the way some men hire honor.

Purcell stood with a pen making small notes that were more theatre than fact, and then he made a show of not needing them. It was almost charming, the way he admired himself for knowing when to pretend to be untidy. “Inspector,” he said, with a softness that tried to reassign her to his register, “we can agree, can we not, that nothing in this case is vulgar.”

He wanted to draw her into Leonard’s diction without admitting he was doing Leonard’s work for him. She thought of pie tins and peppermint and the particular male obsession with the word vulgar when it wants to perform a purity complicated by hunger. “We can agree nothing was messy by accident,” she said, and watched his mouth do the delicate flinch of a man who has been prevented from rolling his eyes.

He took her through process rather than content, because process can be made coy. Why had she gone to the pumping station the second time. Why had she lifted a panel others might not have noticed. Did she not think it romantic, Inspector, to speak of iron singing. Did she not think she had been primed by the boy’s drawing to hear music where there was only the creak of old metal. Had she misremembered a hum into a hymn.

She breathed out like the pool had taught her, felt the tile in her hand, and looked at the jury rather than at Purcell’s slick assurances. “There is a difference,” she said, and left a space, because men like Purcell cannot stand spaces and will fill them for you if you give them trust. “Between romance and attention. He told the boy the iron sang. The boy told me. I heard it. We found the panel there. The memory card was taped to the underside with a label. You can call it romance. I call it listening to a child.”

He tried the doorcode for River Street again. Had she not encouraged her officers to try a number at many doors until one had opened, as if the city were a toy with a loose latch. Had she not, Inspector, gone looking for north-facing windows like a woman in a poem. She told him there had been warrants. She told him the code had been found in pencil on the back of a canvas and that the law had given them what they needed to test its truth. She did not tell him about stepping on gravel barefoot. She felt the bottom of the lane under her fingers and counted to four.

“And you swim,” he said abruptly, because he had thought of it and could not resist, even as his better self tested the word and told him it was petty. “It is part of your image. Does it not—how did you put it—keep your head from narrating. Is that not a strange thing for a witness to claim.”

She let herself smile because she could see the juror on the end shift his jaw, seeing the trick and disliking it. “I swim at six in the morning,” she said. “I count to make room in my head for other people’s narratives, Mr Purcell. It makes me a better witness. It also makes me intolerant of sloppy lanes.”

The room, starved for a small kindness, allowed itself the human release of laughter. He let it sit because he had to, and because his own joke had been too mean to keep. He moved on. He put to her, as if kindly, that the boy had not been harmed. He said the words camp bed with a mildness that could not help suggesting cleanliness. He said water in a glass with a lid, he said he slept and was not cold, he said dinosaur shirt, which someone in the public seats behind her just audibly exhaled at, and the judge said nothing because judges know sometimes a room needs to breathe even if the official prescription forbids it.

“Mr Purcell,” she said, because Hendry had told her to borrow the names when they needed to be made to belong to her for a second, “a child is not unharmed because the linen is pressed. He was taken from his parents without permission. He was told his dragon was wrong. He was told joy was mess. He was taken to be turned into someone else’s lesson. You can decide to call that clean. We can agree to call it what it is.”

He gave up the clean argument because even he did not wish to hear himself polishing that word again. He gestured at her notes with a flourish of boredom. “You wrote about hate,” he said, as if she had doodled between calls. “You wrote ‘He hates quietly.’ We are not here to try quiet hate, Inspector. We are here to try—what? A man who does not like turpentine.”

“We’re here to try abduction,” she said, turning her own mouth away from the taste of peppermint. “We’re here to try planning. We’re here to talk about the difference between correction and theft.”

He put his pen down. “Thank you, Inspector,” he said, and the thank you had the shape of a dismissal that had not quite achieved its clean line. She stepped down and felt her leg do the small tremble that comes when your body mutinies against your stupidity for having believed you could hold still forever. She caught it with the same hand she used to hold cold water at the end of a lane and it let itself be brought back into line.

In the corridor, Hendry let his shoulders drop their performance. “He wanted to make you the poem,” he said, like a man commenting on wind. “Well done for making yourself a weather report.” Lindsey had two coffees and three words. “You were fine,” she said. “Eat this,” she added, and handed her a biscuit that flaked in the morally ambiguous way of shop biscuits trying to pass for bakery.

Elliot Vane sat in the witness room with his hands arranged as if they were frightened of each other. He had not dressed for court well; his earnestness had chosen his shirt and his shirt had failed him. He looked at Hinsley as if seeking permission to continue existing. “I’ve brought the notebook,” he said, small and belligerent at the same time. “The one with the copied bits. Not because I want to help you. Because I want to stop other boys from finding it in my room and thinking it was clever.”

He put it on the table like an apology and then made himself look at Leonard when his turn came. He spoke about north light because the court had not yet had enough of that phrase. He spoke about standards, about wanting lines to mean something. Purcell tried to make him speak about parades, to catch him praising a day as vulgar and then calling it filthy and then being made to choose. He surprised them all and said, simply, “I don’t like crowds. They make me feel untidy. That isn’t a politics. That’s my nerves.” He looked at her when he said nerves, as if asking whether he could live with that word. She let her mouth do the smallest yes it could manage without being theatrical, and he squared himself as if given back not innocence but the permission to stop pretending purity was a profession.

Callum Dyer was less easy. His decency, such as it was, had been sharpened by shame into a tool he kept turning around in his hands without commitment. He said he liked rooms with rules. He said he delivered because people asked and because he wanted to be included among men whose sentences lined up. He tried to save the patches on his jacket by calling them souvenirs, and then he heard himself and put his hand over the place where a patch had been, the universal gesture for covering a hole you cannot mend in public. Purcell offered him the out of logistics, the romantic word that absolves boys without making them feel small. He did not take it fully. The juror on the end wrote down something and underlined it twice, and she found herself irrationally wanting to know if it was pie, peppermint, north, or simply help.

After lunch, the defense brought a theologian, which was almost funny. He was not that by profession—the bar would never permit such spectacle—but he had written a pamphlet about purity of line in sacred art and the way modern pigments had altered the memory of saints. He delivered very careful sentences about correction that never once mentioned Geoff from the Restorers or Dyer’s till or Elliot’s shame. He had the kind of voice that makes people at parties stand near the radiator and forget to refresh their drinks. Hendry let him have his say and then asked him a single question about boys and pies and whether the word correction absolved you of stealing sugar. The man flushed, which pleased no one, and the judge gently intervened before a metaphor hurt someone.

Mara, the fish-stamp seller, testified with her chin up like a small mast. She did not much like being in a room where men did sentences on her behalf, but she liked that she had not died because of a man who built polite evil. She rolled up her sleeve and showed them the fish on her wrist because the usher had told her to remove jewellery and she had refused to remove that and the judge had ruled, with the weary grace of men who have learned to husband their authority, that drawings do not count as ornaments. She spoke of being watched and done kindness to by men who wanted to make it hurt later. She told them about boxes with ribbons and the way a lie can make your day beautiful for three minutes and then ruin a month. She kept her voice from doing an anger she did not yet feel safe allowing itself, and Hinsley wanted very much to stand behind her the whole time as if a body could be a wall.

The Restorers had sent two sympathizers to sit in the gallery and be ordinary. They were good at that. No cause that aspires to decency will send a man who can only roar. They wore jackets that cost money but did not tell you so. They looked, twice, at Hinsley’s hair when she shook it back after a long answer and decided not to make a note of that because it would cheapen their neatness. Outside, one of their younger boys chalked Audit Now on the pavement at the side entrance in a clean hand and then hovered as if waiting for someone to congratulate him on his copybook. He did not expect the woman with the shanty songs to appear with a bucket and a laugh she refused to swallow and a brush that had painted over worse. She told him to hold the other end of the handle and then made him move his arms, and he looked around for a witness who would find this humiliation delicious and saw only a police officer chewing gum like a sacrament and a cat crossing the road with no respect for court schedules. He dragged water. The chalk made its small tired capitulation. He learned better with his hands than he would have online and kept his mouth quiet in a new way.

That evening, Rune sent her a photograph of a window with ice on its edges doing the old trick of making the world outside look as if it had been painted by a hand that fancied itself better than it was. He wrote two words that in Swedish share a parent and yet disagree like siblings about the dinner table. Dom and döma—judgement and to judge—and then, because he could not help needing to make it usable, he wrote the idiomatic for steady your hands. She read it while a pub spilled men arguing about the match into the street and thought how much of life is deciding which words you are allowed to use in your head without inflaming something that does not need to be set on fire.

On the third day, Leonard chose to speak. It was not wise, according to Purcell, but wise is a poor argument with a man who believes a room is owed his tidiness. He came in like a teacher late to Assembly, with apology arranged as posture. He looked smaller because court reduces all men to the size of their wrists. He spoke about color with a care that, if it had been applied to people, might have saved him. He did not say the words he wanted to say because he had promised Purcell he would dress the hatred in a suit that fit. He said “correct” again and the juror on the end made a mark that looked like the opposite of an exclamation. He said he had taken the boy to teach him quiet and to prepare a lesson for the city that had refused to look where light is faithful. He said the word purity once and then corrected himself in public and said decency, the human synonym that hides the old offense under new paint. He told them he had never harmed a child. He told them he had harmed flags and then had replaced them with his own humility. He told them he had washed tins and folded paper and kept rooms proper and that he had done nothing that did not in the end come down to helping.

Hendry asked him, without touching any of the nouns Leonard had chosen out of his little museum, why the boy had been taken without permission. He asked him whether correction ever needed a key. He asked him if he liked peppermint because peppermint made his fantasies smell polite. Leonard, hungry to show that he had invented every sentence there was in this story, admitted he could have telephoned a parent and told them about dragons and could have invited them to bring the boy to the annex and could have explained north light to them like an uncle who has learned physics without getting dirty. He had not. He believed permission had become vulgar in this city. He did not say vulgar, but he breathed the word, and the room, which had been good to him, changed its mind about him precisely then.

That night, she did not go to the pool. She went to the river and stood in a place where you can see the black water come in under the old brick like a steady unspooling of ribbon. The city had allowed itself a small celebration of propriety on the court steps in the form of a choir that had no permit and did not need one. A woman sang a song in a language Hinsley did not speak and others hummed their acceptance around it. Mara sat on the low wall and stamped her fish by torchlight for children whose parents had decided it was worth being out in the dark if they could be whispered into feeling less alone. Lindsey leaned on a railing in that way she has when she is refusing to rest. The superintendent had gone home to a house that made more noise than he had planned when he designed his life, and the ponytail analyst had taken the long way, because sometimes a bike needs to be ridden not to a destination but to a more useful mood.

On Day Four, the cross-examinations had begun to feel like men trying to braid hair without admitting they envied its gloss. There was a rhythm to version and error that even the judge’s patience could not make fresh. She watched Purcell reach for the same handful of nouns and twist them into new orders and wished for a little salt on the entire enterprise. Then, in the afternoon, the weather gave them something to attend to. The sky darkened too quickly for a day in this month. The lights in the courtroom made everything look like a rehearsal. A child cried outside in a corridor in a way that made every mother in the building flinch with muscle memory, even the ones who had never had children.

There was a smell, faint and wrong, of oil made hot on too-small rags. Her body recognized it before her discipline could make her keep her seat. She stood and said in a steady voice that the usher would approve of, “Your Honour, there may be a small matter outside,” and the judge, who did not like being told about the weather by a witness, nevertheless nodded because his nose had a loyalty to the world his training could not erase. They emptied the court with the clean efficiency of a school drill and found in the service corridor a miracle: a small fire beginning itself without theatre, a handful of cloth that had been used to wipe brushes and then tucked into a corner the way boys tuck guilt into boxes under beds. A young man stood looking at it with honest horror and on his jacket the lighthouse had not yet been unpicked.

“Bucket,” Eva said, because she had arrived like weather and had brought with her that old, practical sound. The caretaker had a bucket because Rune was right: older men and buckets save us. They doused the heat before it could decide to stand up and become a hero. The young man cried and told them he had wanted to show decency with a gesture and had not realized—he had not realized—that the rags had lives beyond paint. His hands shook. He let himself be lectured, which was new. He let himself be escorted out, which would make his online sentences different the next day or not at all.

“Rags,” Lindsey said later, leaning on her desk with all the grace of an exhausted aunt. “Rags will do us in faster than any plan.” Hinsley nodded because she did not know how to answer in a way that would not make her feel clever, and cleverness is the enemy of this work. She thought of Rune, of the whistle, of the bucket, of the boy with the wrists, of the men in their club-making sentences. She texted two words, because Swedish had made her greedy for the economy of certain pairs that do more than their count. Whistle. Bucket. He sent back an address in Stockholm where a bucket could be bought from a man who would look at you and know whether you had learned your lesson about rags and say nothing if you had.

On the last day before the judge took the narrative and gave it the shape his robe demanded, Mara appeared at the back with a parcel tied with string, the sensible kind, not the theatrical rag of ribbon that allows lies to dress as gifts. Inside were stamps she had carved new: boats with dragon eyes, fish with lighthouse fins, small clever things that children could press into wrists and know that they belonged to a city that makes its signs in public because secrets make boys like Leonard believe themselves necessary. She had written a note with printing that took itself seriously because it had decided it had to. For the baby walls, she’d scrawled, as if the sides of buildings were children you could scold and then feed.

Hendry stood to close with a modesty that made the room lean in. He told the jury to put away the romance that men had tried to sell them. He told them to keep the peppermint and the dragon and the north light only insofar as those words helped them see that planning had been done by a mind in love with itself and that a boy had been taken from his name and moved into a room whose cleanliness had no compassion in it. He refused to say the word hate. He refused to say vulgar. He gave them abduction, and then he gave them a single word that had no Latin bones in it, that belonged to mothers who find their children and to men who queue for their bread and to lifeguards with paperbacks and to caretakers with buckets. Take.

Purcell’s closing had angles. He asked them to consider the difference between harm and fear. He asked them to separate songs from evidence. He asked them if the city had not kept its own counsel about what it calls care and whether a man who disapproved of parades might not be guilty simply of a sentence uttered in a the wrong place. He smiled at them in the way men in his line have learned persuades men at parties. He made a small, elegant case for a technical mercy. He did not ever convince the room he had met the boy on the camp bed.

They retired. The jury went to make their small weather upstairs. The building performed the quiet it performs when it wants to remind itself it is a theatre, not a home. Lindsey chewed gum and then produced a fresh stick and then did the kindness of offering it to Purcell, who took it because he had been taught politeness by a woman in a kitchen when he was ten and sometimes those habits rescue courts more than rules do. They did not speak about outcomes. They spoke about buckets and rags because even silk-lined rooms like to pretend they are kinder when they perform the practical.

She did not wait in the corridor with the others. She went down to the ramp that leads to a side door where men with cigarettes socialize their nerves, and she watched the rain decide to be light after all. Mara joined her, because Mara had learned to put herself where edges exist. “If they say no,” Mara said, maybe to see what the word felt like on her tongue, “I will stamp the houses with more fish than they can wash. If they say yes, I will still stamp. It’s not their job to finish these things.”

“It is nobody’s job to finish them,” Hinsley said. “We just put better hinges on the ugly doors.” She thought of the panel at the pumping station and how the lie in the rivet pattern had let a man become neat in a way he had no right to be. She thought of hinges and wanted to be ridiculous and go buy some. She would not. She would go home after and water orchids and count and be ordinary and that, too, would be part of her vocation.

When the verdict came—quickly, because sometimes the city allows itself the decency of ah yes rather than hmm—the word that mattered was the one that had belonged to Hendry and then to her and then to the jurors. Guilty. There would be sentences later about how many years and whether a man who liked north light could be made to live under strip bulbs that cannot help singing. There would be appeals written with courtesy and peeled apart with equal courtesy. There would be boys online who would say standards have fallen and other boys who would delete an app and go to an art room where a woman would put linseed rags in a bucket and teach them something older men had taught her. There would be a parade next year and someone would draw a dragon without asking permission and a man would look at it and decide to keep his mouth closed for once because the room had taught him this type of silence.

She went home because she had learned to give herself home as a prize for not having ruined the day. She put the fish magnet straight because it had decided again to be comedic and look as if it were falling. She poured Rune’s tea for the taste of chemical winter on the tongue and because in a week she would need to be seen in Stockholm again in a kitchen where the light admits its own weather. The orchids looked back at her with their precise ridiculousness. She put a towel on the back of a chair to keep herself from going to bed with wet hair and met the towel’s insistence as if it were a person. Then she sat on the floor with her back against the cabinet and let the day remove itself from her bones inch by careful inch.

Later, when the city had decided to call it night, she walked to the river without needing to as if the water had asked. It made its old sounds and a new one, because verdicts alter the timbre of streets even if they do not change the notes. On the railing, chalk had returned in small abundance. Fish with hearts in their eyes. Dragons whose fire was not red. A lighthouse with a speech bubble that said BUCKETS, which would have made Rune snort and then become solemn. Next to it, someone had written in spelling that had been learned with difficulty and love: CLEAN IS KIND, NOT CRUEL. She stood there until her fingers were cold and then warmed them under her arms like a bird. She counted. She let the counting be the only sentence she chose. Then she went home and slept without rehearsing. In the morning she would swim. In the afternoon she would eat a bun that had too much sugar. In the evening she would look at an old file full of new names. Between those acts she would allow herself one small private vulgarity, which is to say she would go to the museum gift shop and buy a model boat and not assemble it and keep it on a shelf because it is sometimes enough to know that a ship could be made by your hands and to leave it unmade as a way of promising yourself gentler work later.

On the mornings she could not sleep, she went to the pool. There were three open-air lanes kept warm even in the early hours, steam rising from them like the breath of something sleeping. Hinsley dove without the little ritual she used to do in Stockholm—blowing out air, counting heartbeats—and cut through the surface with muscle memory that never abandoned her. Fifty meters, turn, fifty again. Shoulders woke. The quiet came.

By the time the first gulls screamed and wheeled, the city had started making its lists. Trams eying their tracks, restaurants dumping yesterday’s parsley, men in fluorescent jackets trading jokes in low voices. Hinsley had already done a thousand meters. The lifeguard had a paperback and a bored expression that bordered on hostility. When she finished, she toweled herself without looking up and only then found that her phone had shivered itself off the bench. Six calls. One from Control. One from Lindsey, who never called this early unless it was something. Four from a landline she didn't recognize, the number no longer attached to anyone in her phone.

She took the last one first. A man's voice, trembling and trying not to. "This is—this is Mr. Ash. My boy hasn't come home." He said boy like the word was made of spun sugar you couldn't put your tongue to without ruining it. "Jamie. He's nine. He was at the river fair and then, we couldn't find him, and, they said to call you. The lady said, is that the—what's it called—the senior person. She said you'd know what to do."

"Mr. Ash," she said, glancing at the lifeguard, who was yawning now, a cavern of a mouth, "it's Detective Chief Inspector Hinsley. I'm going to call you back in three minutes. Stay with someone. Do not go searching alone."

"I—"

"Three minutes," she said, already poking Control.

Control told her he'd been missing two hours. The fair had been by the riverwalk, the one that always felt like a relative had tried too hard to be fun. Balloons, a face painting stall, a woman who sang sea shanties in a voice that made children warp their mouths into clocks of awe, a man with a puppet on his hand and another puppet on his shoulder. Food trucks. Tinny music. Lindsey had already been in touch with uniformed.

"Have we got CCTV?" Hinsley asked, rubbing her hair out of her eyes as she pushed into the changing room.

"Patchy. One of the stalls blocked sightlines. We have him at 18:14 by a stall with a hand-painted sign."

"Which sign?"

"Children in color."

Her stomach blurred. She sat down on the cold tile, water pooling by her toes. On the other end of the line, Control breathed and filled her ear with the smell of coffee, the change between breaths of someone who didn't know what else to offer.

"Get me Lindsey," she said, and by the time she walked out into the silvered air, wearing trousers and a sweater pulled on over wet skin, she had her sergeant on a line.

"We've sealed off the fair," Lindsey said without preamble. "Parents are in a tent. They're calling him Jamie while they pretend to say child and missing. We've got a description, and we have a hundred people who saw a boy with a dinosaur on his shirt. Boys everywhere apparently wear dinosaurs. It's like a uniform."

"And the stall?"

"Face painter, yeah. Guy named Leonard. No surname on file. Took card payments only. Packed up right before the parents realized Jamie was gone. The woman who sang shanties says she saw a man in a flat cap lift a crate into a van with a paint-smeared hand. White van. I know."

She knew. The white van was a cliché that every missing person case tried on like a coat. It rarely fit. "Give me ten minutes," she said. "I'm fifteen away."

On the drive, the city was a grid of gray and then it wasn't; river opened suddenly and the buildings leaned away as if they were being polite. The fair was a mess of color with no organizing principle. Balloons slumped. Wet paper decorations stuck to fences in a way that looked accidental and permanent.

Uniformed kept the parents at a kind angle, as if they might break if handled with bluntness. Mr. Ash was the sort of man who looked younger when frightened: pale, freckles from youth that had returned as if called, a hoodie with a smear of paint that she couldn't help noticing. Mother—Ms. Toller—flicked her eyes at faces and then away as if they were too bright. They'd been co-parenting for three years, on and off. Neither wanted to say the boy had walked away because of a sourness about who had him that day. Neither wanted to implicate the other. Hinsley took their names, the tirade of facts new parents regurgitate when someone suggests their child is an idea that could be lost.

"He likes lizards," Mr. Ash said. "And cinnamon buns. And the sound of bicycle wheels on metal. He—he always stops to listen to that."

"And the stall," Hinsley said. "Tell me about the stall."

"We didn't even go near it," Ms. Toller said too quickly, and then realized the defensiveness in her voice and softened it. "He doesn't like having his face touched. He had a cold last month and it made him… you know. But he likes to watch. We walked past and he stopped dead. He was watching this cartoon picture, this chalkboard the painter had with a sample drawing of a dragon and a knight. And then he wasn't right behind me. I turned around and—"

Then he wasn't right behind me. That sentence had an echo in it under everything they built. It sounded like tunnels under a city, carrying meanings that would whistle back at you when you called into them.

Hinsley walked the fair, hands in her pockets, eyes ahead. In a bin near the stall site was a tower of plastic cups and a smear of something that had once been purple and now had decided to be brown. She found tacks that had held the stall ropes, three sips of a soda left in a paper cup, a button that said I'm A Tiny Pirate. A child had cried there, recently; there was that smeared crescent of sandy tears that always happened when cheeks weren't clean to begin with. The sign from the stall had been painted in thick letters with the flourishes of someone who couldn't help themselves. Children in Color, and below it in smaller letters, portraits while you wait.

Lindsey came to her, looking surprisingly tall in a coat that made her shoulders square. "We found the cash box from the stall behind the portaloo," she said. "Ten pounds in coins. No notes."

"He wasn't there for the money," Hinsley said.

"Is anyone anywhere?"

"We can be," she said, mostly to herself.

They found the white van on a traffic camera later that day. It had a fish sticker on the back window. Their techs read the plate. The plate led them to a man who hadn't renewed his insurance in seven months and claimed he'd sold the van to a friend who didn't have a last name.

"I call him Len," the man said, shrugging as if shrugging could absolve you of vagueness. "He came by the community center sometimes, you know, to paint. Kids liked 'im. I dunno what you're suggesting."

"We're suggesting we'd like to find him," Lindsey said pleasantly, but without the smile she used when she actually liked someone.

"He's a good one," the man insisted. "Bit—bit old-fashioned. Does a lot with proper paints, none of that plastic nonsense. Said color was a responsibility. Talked odd, is all. He—" The man hesitated. "He asked if we had rules about certain events. Like… parade stuff. He don't like that. But he kept it to himself."

The word parade stained the air in a particular way. Hinsley thought of last summer, the flags, the music. The little pockets of people on the pavement with their dogs. The few angry faces outside the price of admission. Leonard would have watched from a shadow and pressed his mouth into a line you could cut paper with. Hating, yes, in the privacy of his head, and perhaps that was all. Perhaps.

They had a list of Leonard sightings, and none of them were the same man. To the woman from the shanty stall, he had slicked hair and a narrow face like a knife. To the bouncy castle operator, he had been stout, cheerful, thick fingers good at brushwork. To the girl with the popcorn he had looked like her dad in a hurry. That always happened; it was like the city gave the bad ones a cloak.

By evening the river had become a belt of dark water so tight it held everything together. They had teams trawling and teams at the station watching hours of footage that all seemed to show nothing and then showed a sliver of something that looked like hope and then rewound to reveal a leaf. She met with the parents again. Mr. Ash had been offered a cup of tea and rejected it as if considering it insulted his son somehow; Ms. Toller clutched hers two-handed, as if there were consequences to warming only one hand at a time.

"We'll find him," Hinsley said because she believed she could build a yes from enough details. It wasn't optimism. It was muscle memory.

"Detective," the father said. "I keep thinking he's gone to see the river from the bridge, like he always wants to. I keep thinking he's standing looking down and thinking about how the water moves, and maybe he's, he's—"

She knew what sentence he wouldn't finish. She knew because every parent wanted to share guilt with statistics, for a second, before rejecting both. "He's a child," she said softly. "He's nine, and he had a dinosaur on his shirt. He didn't choose to go anywhere alone."

When she left them, she walked to the bridge. The water made the sound of secret words told to someone who wouldn't keep them. Gulls screamed and a bus shuddered over the metal grates, and she did as she had told herself to do that morning: she counted heartbeats until her own decided to calm.

At home there were two orchids she had kept alive for longer than any relationship in the last five years, a rowing medal from when she thought changing sports would change her body, and her step-father's postcard stuck to the fridge with a magnet shaped like a fish. Rune wrote as if every sentence had a thesis. Stockholm is gray and good, he had written in March. We saw the old men swimming in the Baltic this morning, naked as reasons. He never called what he and she were anything. When her mother married Rune, she had expected an interloper with a hat and opinions. Rune had brought cinnamon buns and tidal charts. When her mother died, years later, he'd lost his way around human beings but still made coffee with a seriousness that had no place to go.

She called him now. The unknown landline had been him, she realized, the moment she heard the breath he took before speaking her name. "Alva?"

"I'm in a case," she said, using her birth name because Rune would always call her that. "What did you need?"

"Nothing. I wanted to check your throat, which is to say the way you sounded in the last letter. If the good people of this island are treating you with basic kindness."

"They are. I'm—I'm swimming again."

He breathed a small, satisfied noise. "Good. Do not overdo. You'll get a tendon injury if you try to pretend you're seventeen. You were quite invincible then. It didn't suit you."

She smiled at the ceiling. "I'll call you this weekend. We might need you to send more of that peppermint tea you buy from the old woman."

"Tell me where," he said, but she could hear him smile. Neither of them said the name of her mother. Neither of them said the phrase step-daughter, which always felt like a path with boards missing.

The first call came at two in the morning. It was a receptionist at the station, voice tight the way voices get tight when they are trying not to let the shape of fear widen. "I've got a delivery here that I don't want to… to deal with. It is labeled for you. It's a pie."

The city did not sleep as much as people thought. Cabs drew lines between corners of stories. A fox in the headlights looked like a question someone had thrown on the road. When she reached the station, the pie sat in a cardboard box on the desk. There was a note written in a hand that tried to be tidy and failed.

Color isn't a toy. Real color takes from you and gives back if it wishes.

She looked at the pie and did not think of recipes. She thought of the word ritual and breathed very slowly. The receptionist hovered in an orbit that kept them both safe.

"Don't touch it," she said, and realized how unnecessary the order was. They bagged it. They didn't open it. She didn't want anyone to have to think of fillings. She wanted someone to tell her that pies couldn't hurt you. The note she kept in a plastic sleeve, the way you would press a flower you weren't sure you should keep.

They'd find out later that it was mince with cinnamon, all grocery-store ingredients, nothing to fear beyond the taunt. Later still they would find out that the base crust had been saturated with an oil used in painting, the expensive kind, the kind that left a smell for years in old studios. It was, she thought when she eventually slept for an hour, like someone had tried to write in a language where meaning was all shadows.

In the morning, reports stacked up like loaves. Lindsey caught her at the machine in the corner, which made the sort of coffee that tasted of labor but not reward.

"We have another," Lindsey said. "Not a kid. A stall owner from the riverside market. She's missing. Her daughter says she didn't come home. She sells hand-cut stamps, little seals. Lots of fish and boats. Very nice. I bought a seagull from her once that made my cat distrust me."

"Were they near the painter?"

"Two stalls down."

"Get me all faces who were there," she said. "Even the man dressed as a lighthouse. Especially him."

"On it. Also—" Lindsey hesitated, then pushed on. "There’s chatter. Someone says they saw our white van at the docks last night. Could be nothing."

"It always could be," she said, and went to see the empty place where the stamp-seller had been. There were traces, as there always were. A bit of packing string. A stamp that had fallen under the plank and sat now with its face inked in blue, crooked and stubborn. It was a fish. She put it in a bag.

Behind the stalls, in the alley where everyone pretended secrets were not made, there was a smear on the brick like someone had brushed it with their hand. It wasn't blood. She didn't need it to be blood to recognize the wrongness. It smelled faintly of peppermint and something like varnish. She remembered Rune's talk about oils and turpentine as if they were old friends who deserved respect. "It can make you see in two dimensions if you don't watch yourself," he had said once, after a flight where they had looked down at the islands scattered like bones. "You must insist on a third."

Her third dimension was always people. She found the shanty singer—Eva, long gray hair and a voice that made every story sound as if it had a boat tethered at the end of it—and asked her to sing the memory of the man again without words. How he had moved, where he had stood. They walked it. Eva sang and walked, and at a corner she stopped, hair falling forward like a curtain.

"He came from there," she said, pointing at the narrow gap between the pub and the bakers. "There was a smell like, like peppermint, yes. And something gone wrong."

She put uniformed at that gap and asked them to watch. She didn't think he'd come back, not there, but sometimes the bad ones orbit their own guilt.

He was, perhaps, in a basement at that moment. He was cleaning brushes. He was telling himself that color had to be earned. He might have had a book open next to him, not a holy book, nothing with gilding. He might have gathered words he liked like collector's spoons, polishing one and setting another on a shelf. He might have repeated a phrase about mistakes of men who loved men, about wrongness braided into cities like power lines. And he would have loved to make it all literal, to make a pie of it, to feed the city its own. He would hold on to the thought like an anchor when his old fear rose—the fear that he was small and sick-colored and nothing would ever make him proper size.

No one knew him yet. He didn't know they were saying his name in rooms that smelled of coffee and inadequate carpet cleaner.

Hinsley went home for a shower and found she could not turn on the water. The day stuck to her skin anyway, so what difference would a bath make. In the mirror her shoulders were a swimmer's, still. Her hair had in it a silver thread that she had noticed last month and let be. She thought of Stockholm's water, dark and cold, and then thought of the river here, which was darker, more crowded, full of very different fish.

Her phone vibrated. Rune again. "Alva, I only want to say good morning," he said when she answered, in the tone he used for the phrase I'm worried. "The coffee is hot and the sky pretends to be clear. I have sent the tea. Do not argue."

She sat on the bed that still had damp in it from last night's wet sweater. "We have a boy missing," she told him, because when she tried to talk about anything else the words felt like pictures with no captions.

"Then he will be found," Rune said, not cheerily but as if he were setting frames around the words to hold them. "This is your work. You swim. You find. You breathe again."

"I don't breathe again," she said quietly. "I just change water."

"Then change water," he said, not unkindly.

By afternoon, they had a thin thread. The man with the puppet had seen the white van again; he'd followed it for a bit on his bike because he was bored and because the van felt like the start of a story. It had turned into a street by the old mill that children called the Goblin House. That name belonged to some ancient rumor that the foundations were wrong, that the first owners had buried something not proper under it. Children told each other in schoolyards that goblins came and painted your face and then you became a pie. Children made so many jokes about pies. Children had the right to be stupid, Hinsley thought, with a sudden clarity that hurt.

The mill had become lofts and cafés years ago, expensive sinks and exposed brick. Behind it were still older buildings, the kinds with basements and iron doors. They went there with a warrant that had corners like knives; they made everyone stand outside. The café owner complained about the smell of police. Someone cried because a police dog had looked at them too hard. In the end it was the bakery that made it. The owner was sallow and obsequious and told them the basement was damp but the ovens were clean as a god's conscience.

In the basement someone had drawn circles on the concrete with chalk. Someone had filled a jar with something like oil that had the scent of a winter sweet forced into summer. There were brushes laid out like cutlery. No blood. Thank every unfinished god. There was a sheet of paper with sketches. Children in profile. Clean lines with too much attention to ears.

"Leonard," Lindsay whispered, as if saying the name might conjure a particular shade, something you could blend only once you heard it aloud.

"He paints what he wants to keep," Hinsley said, surprising herself with the certainty in her own voice. "He keeps what he thinks takes the color out of the world. I don't know. It's—"

"Not rational," Lindsey provided. "Criminal offenses rarely are."

"It is rational to him. That's worse."

They took the brushes and the jar and the paper. They did not yet have a person to attach to the space. The bakery had a camera but it had been turned to the wall. The baker swore he had never touched it. "There are kids down here sometimes," he said sullenly. "For club meetings. I rent the room for quizzes. I don't remember names. I don't have to."

"You do, actually," Hinsley said. "Get me the list. Right now."

He wheedled and prevaricated and eventually produced a sheaf of crumpled sign-in sheets with bogus team names and a few real first names. Leonard might not be stupid enough to write his. But perhaps one of his orbit did. A name recurred: Lenn. With two n's. It stood out because people who abbreviate write gently; this one had been pressed into paper.

There was a moment then—sitting on a stool in a baking-smelling room, under pipes that breathed, under the cages of light that made everyone's faces look gentler—when she felt something like progress. The kind of progress that in detective stories is a line you draw with a red pencil on a map. In life it was more like stepping stones asking you to guess where the next one was.

In a different place, under a bridge, a man sat with his back against a stone and recited the names of colors. Carmine. Viridian. Payne's Gray. There were colors he would never say. He had built a small temple to them in himself and bricked up the door. He had been told, long ago in a classroom that smelled of damp coats, that color made people dance with each other in ways that sickened him. He had started hating then, neatly, like laying cutlery in rows. When the city put flags up, when the city paraded, he had walked at night and taken down some flags with the efficient quiet hands of someone replacing bad books with good ones on a shelf.

He ate a piece of pie and thought about how what you consumed became you and then thought about how to make what you were feed the world in a righteous way. He didn't want to hurt children. He told himself that. He was making a larger point, a deeper lesson, a palate needed to be cleansed. The thoughts were slippery but he held on. He had always been small; in stories, the small ones were allowed to be clever and mean. He could do mean with a craftsman's care. He had never used slurs like the men in the pub because he thought that was vulgar. He dressed hatred in better clothes. He would have been appalled to be called a bigot. He would have claimed to be a restorer of old colors.

He sharpened a pencil. He washed his hands to the wrist. He thought of pie, which was kindness and order; everything contained and baked properly. He wrote the word Leonard in a notebook and then crossed it out and wrote Lenn, because he was not the man people thought when they heard "Leonard." He was not anyone anyone thought, and that was his favorite part. And he made a plan, negligible in its steps, which is to say careful. He would visit the docks. He would go by the fish market where the ice made little mountains. He would set a thing down in the path of a woman he had seen buy a stamp in the shape of a fish. He would watch until her walk changed. He was good at watching walks change.

Hinsley didn't know his steps, but she felt they existed the way a swimmer knows currents without seeing them. She sat at her desk and looked at the photographs of the fair. She pinned them with pushpins in a pattern that was part logic, part the body of A to B. She drank coffee she did not need and texted Rune without meaning to: Tea arrived. Thank you. He texted a fish and a heart, which was new.

"They're doing a sweep of the docks again," Lindsey said from the doorway.

"Bring them a thermos," Hinsley said.

"You do it. They like you."

"They like you more. You don't tell them about swimmers in the dark."

"They don't tell you about their boats, so we're even," Lindsey said. Then she sobered. "His parents are in the waiting room. They didn't want to go home."

Her legs did not want to stand but did. She went to sit with Mr. Ash and Ms. Toller while the city kept its secrets. She told them about what a day does when you're missing someone: how the light changes without your permission, how you get angry at paper cups. She didn't tell them that sometimes the color of a morning is the last color you remember properly for a while. That was not useful.

"Will you call us if you find—if you hear," Ms. Toller said.

"I will," she said.

"Even if it's late? Even if it's bad?"

"Yes." Then she did something she did rarely; she told them about her mother. "My mother left Sweden when I was twelve," she said, the words feeling like stepping on gravel barefoot. "She didn't speak the language here. She learned to listen to people roll their r's like stones. She got lost and then she got found again. She married someone who showed her the tide tables until she could read them like poems. She died, and I thought there would never be color again. It came back. Not the same. But it came back. I'm saying this because you're going to feel like nothing exists that isn't this. Something else will be there later. It won't replace this. It will just stand next to it and hold hands with it."

They looked at her as if she had brought a gift wrapped badly. They took it anyway. People do.

In the evening, she did a thing she had not done in months. She went to the water. Not the pool. The open water at the end of the old pier, where the youth diving club leaped in summer. No one was there now. The surface had the look of iron though it had no metal in it. She didn't go in. She stood and breathed the cold until it felt like an old friend had come to meet her halfway. She thought of Rune at his window with his tea, looking at the Baltic and the islands shaped like sleeping animals. She thought of Jamie, who liked lizards and bicycle sounds and the color of cinnamon buns, which is not a single color but a set of ideas.

Behind her someone coughed. She turned fast enough to make her neck ache. A woman with a dog smiled apologetically and walked on. Hinsley laughed, just once, without humor. Then she went back to the car.

On the seat was a leaflet someone had slid under the wiper. It was for a local dance night. The logo was a hand-painted heart in a style that looked almost old-fashioned. The heart had a claw mark through it like a flourish. She turned it over. On the back, a small stamp of a fish.

The stamp-seller, then. It wasn't a clue so much as a plea: look for me, maybe. Or someone telling her they'd seen someone else. It could be nothing. It could be everything. She put it in her pocket and felt its corners until they softened.

The night kept moving in the way nights move when they are waiting. She slept in her office for forty minutes with a coat over herself and then woke to Lindsey holding two coffees, one of which she thrust at her like a defibrillator.

"There's a call from the fish market," Lindsey said. "Someone found something left like a prayer. It's… it's a dragon painted on a piece of wood. The kind that a face painter uses to show kids what they could be. The dragon has a little sticker on it that says JAMIE in wobbly letters. I think—"

"I know," Hinsley said, and went to the market.

It was morning in every way now. Men shouted with joy and exasperation over ice. Fish lay like punctuation. The wood with the dragon propped against a crate looked like a sign someone had been forced to read. The paint was thick and clean, lines sure with practice. The sticker had been peeled off and stuck back on; whoever had done it had cared to make it right. That could be kindness. That could be insult. The dragon's eye was green and angry. Under it, small, someone had written in pen: color is a debt.

"We'll get prints," someone said, and did, with careful hands.

A boy missing, a woman missing, a bakery with chalk circles and a note about color, a face painter who didn't exist on the tax records, a van with a fish sticker. A city that liked to play with names, that called old mills goblin houses because someone thought that was funny once. A detective with a swimmer's shoulders and an ache in each that had very little to do with laps.

She went back to the station and looked at the sign-in sheets again. Lenn. Lenn. Lenn with two n's. A phone number scribbled next to one of them had seven digits correct and one wrong, easily. Her eyes crossed. Then she noticed on the edge of one sheet, someone had doodled a fish with a heart for an eye. That was the stamp-seller's motif. Perhaps she had filled in the margins while waiting for friends. Perhaps Leonard had borrowed the pen. She felt foolish for caring. She cared anyway.

At noon, Rune sent her a photo. The Baltic, sheet-steel and choppy, and the edge of his mug in the corner. He didn't caption it. She stood in the fluorescent light and looked at water she could not put her hand in. Then she turned back to the board, to her city, to this river that was now part of the map of her bones whether she liked it or not.

When the call came that the white van had been seen again by the old boatyard, she didn't grab a coat. She ran. The boatyard was a splinter factory with a gate that liked to pretend it protected something. Inside, hulks of boats were set up on metal frames like animals on operating tables, old paint flaking like old arguments. The van stood by a shed, innocuous as bread.

They approached it with care. A dog sniffed, whipped its tail, lost interest. The back door was unlocked. Inside: crates that had held paint, a stack of canvases turned to face inward, a folded tarp. Under the tarp, a box of chalk. The chalk wasn't the children's kind. It was artist's, dense and expensive, the kind that stained anything it touched. Her fingers itched to touch and she didn't.

"Run the plates again," she told Lindsey. "And check second-hand art shops. If he buys good chalk, he sells work somewhere. Even if it's under a different name."

Lindsey nodded. "You eat?" she asked, in the way that policemen and women always ask because they have learned the hard way that skipping meals makes people make bad choices.

"Pie," Hinsley said dryly. "Last night."

"Laugh so you don't cry," Lindsey said, too tired to make it a joke.

And then, because the day had decided it was not done with them, a call came from a charity shop three blocks from the market. A man had brought in a stack of framed child portraits, painted in oil, to donate. The clerk had thought them creepy but not actionable; the frames were nice, though. Then she had heard about Jamie's dragon. She had looked again. The children in the portraits were painted with care that bordered on love, which was maybe the most frightening thing. Their eyes had that glisten of wetness oils can give, of being about to speak. The man had paid for the quart of peppermint tea by tapping; the shop had kept the receipt. The name on the receipt was not Leonard. It was one that would mean nothing to anyone. But the bank would, with a warrant and time, tell them the card belonged to a man named Lenard Briggs, who claimed benefits under a different address and had a record only of fines for public order and petty theft. Someone who thought spelling didn't matter as long as meaning sat still for you.

She stood looking at the portraits, not letting herself think of who each child resembled, if at all. They might have been composites. They might have been practice. She felt her career wasn't big enough to sit under the weight of this painter's idea of the world. She felt small in an unuseful way. Then she squared herself. She had taught her body to slice through cold. Do it now, she told her blood.

On one portrait's back, in pencil so faintly she nearly missed it, was a number. It was a date. It was next week. An appointment, perhaps. He took appointments. He painted while you waited. He'd planned something. It had to be somewhere. The number wasn't a phone. It looked like a doorcode. Something used for a meeting room, maybe. Something used for an outer door to a building with flats above shops. In this city, codes were more common than keys now. She felt her brain do what it loved and hated: take apart a problem and fit it back together until it made a click.

"We need to talk to every building on River Street that uses doorcodes," she told Lindsey. "Use the number. See if it opens anything."

"That's—"

"Mad, yes. Do it anyway. Start with the old ones. Places that look like they should still have keys."

Lindsey grinned, a flash that made her face look like ten years ago. "On it," she said, and left with the portraits and three officers who had woken up a little at the thought of it.

Hinsley stood in the charity shop with the clerk, who had a knitted hat and trembling hands, and thought about how the world asked people like this to be brave without warning. "You did well," she told her.

"I didn't do anything," the woman said, a little angrily.

"You didn't throw them away. That's more than something."

"But you won't—"

"We'll find him," she said again, and the phrase had begun to feel like chalk on her own tongue. It left dust. She swallowed it.

In the evening, she went home for eight minutes and took the mug with Rune's fish magnet and poured tea into it and didn't drink it. The orchids nodded as if they agreed with whatever she hadn't yet said. She picked up the photo Rune had sent and held it to the window until the two bodies of water seemed to meet. It felt like trying to make two pieces of different wood fit without cutting either. Then she put it down, and turned her head, and listened because sometimes a city whispers at you in its air ducts.

In the alley beside her building, someone had chalked a little fish with a heart for an eye. Kids, she thought first. Someone playing at being a sign. Then she saw the note taped above it, small and precise. Color is a debt. She tore it down, quietly. Her hands shook and she used her swimmer's breathing to turn them into useful hands again. She let the patch of wall be just wall.

At dawn, Lindsey called from outside a doorcode-protected building two blocks from the fair. "Boss," she said, trying to sound like this wasn't the best part of her day. "This is it. The code works. The building is a community arts space above a shop that sells model ships. The door opens to a hallway that smells like peppermint oil and stories. Come fast. Bring a warrant if you want but I'm going in."

"Wait two minutes for me," she said, already running. The city blurred into lines and then came into focus, the way it does when what you need to see finally stands still long enough to be seen.

On the stairs there were chalk fingerprints, little beautiful ghosts. Upstairs, a door that had been painted white too many times, a surface with history buried in it. The room beyond was an old classroom that had been turned into a studio. There were canvases stacked and a table laden with jars and, on the far wall, a row of child portraits like the ones from the shop but less finished, beginnings pinned like butterflies.

And there, in the center, a canvas covered with a cloth. She saw Lindsey look at it the way you look at a body of water you know is cold. They lifted it together. Under the cloth, the outline of a boy with a dinosaur on his shirt had been sketched in charcoal, not yet painted, not yet sealed into oil. He had not yet become an idea in the painter's world. He was still potential. She could have knelt and cried and she did not. She stood very still and let that feel like swimming.

"He's got a system," Lindsey said. "He prepares. He does it like a ceremony."

"We break it," Hinsley said.

They tore the place apart, gently. They found receipts with card names and amounts. They found the peppermint oil. They found a copy of a book about pigment history, pages dog-eared to sections on verdigris and lead. They found a notebook with the word Debt written on the first page, and a drawing of a pie that made her want to jump out of her own skin and walk away without it.

They did not find him.

He was elsewhere, taking a slow walk with his shoulders hunched under a coat that made him look like every man on the street who had places to be. He was thinking about all the colors he'd seen and how wrong the parade had looked. He was thinking of the boy with the dinosaur and the sound bicycle wheels make on metal. He would never admit he liked that sound, because liking anything the boy liked felt like softness, and softness had been torn out of him by truths that were not true and by men in pubs who had watched football with the sound off and the commentary in their voices pretending it was moral clarity.

He was going to the stamp-seller's shop. He had a box in his hands with a ribbon because he knew about cover stories. He would ask for a fish. He would say his niece loved them. He would watch the way the woman's face did something when she was kind. He had habits. They would be his undoing.

He walked past a window and a woman glanced up from a cup of tea and saw nothing to remark on. He passed a man who was texting and didn't see him at all. He passed a detective who had stopped to tie her lace because it had undone itself like a small rebellion and didn't look up in time. Later, she would remember the coat and the set of his eyes on nothing and wonder why it had not been a signal. Later is never there when you need it.

By evening, they had a name and a room with walls that told them stories. By midnight, they had warrants and patrols. By morning, they had the feeling that being close and being done were not the same. She could hear the click of the tile under the pool, the echo under the bridge, the words Rune would say to her if he could sit beside her on this ugly chair. Swim. Find. Breathe.

On the third day, a child was found.

It was not Jamie. It was a girl who had been taken to a storage unit and left when something had spooked him. She had purple paint on her cheek, a smear like a comet. She cried and then didn't. She said "the man was small," as if that were the whole of it. She said, "he said I was careless with color," and they would figure out later that she had colored on her father's shoes and that the world had punished her for something that should have been a family joke.

They took her hand prints and the brushwork on her cheek and let them dry. She pointed at the sky and asked if it always looked like it was about to rain here. "Mostly," Hinsley said, and the girl said, "good," as if weather could be an ally.

They set a trap made of ordinary things: a fair scheduled as normal, a stall with face painting run by a woman with a steady hand, a police officer with a dinosaur sticker on his shirt, another with a camera hidden in a paper lantern. People called them ruthless for doing it. People called them heroes for doing it. It didn't matter. It might matter to the boy. It might bring him to the place where they could take him back.

The day was bright in a sharp way. The air had coins in it again, tricked into that by wind off the water. Hinsley wore a cap and stood a little back from the main flow. Lindsey chewed gum like it was a promise. Eva sang a song about boats. The fish stamp seller, who had come back to them safely two nights earlier with a sequence of memory like fish scales—overlapping, reflective—stood with her hands in her pockets and her gaze tethered to the face painting sign as if she could will something into view.

And then they saw him. Not in detail. Not the face that would be drawn later by people who had never met him. They saw the shape of him in the space between one stall and another, the blankness that moved wrong. They saw the fingers of his hand, the way they wanted to hold a brush even when they held nothing. They saw the way he looked at the sign, and the way he looked away from the two men standing under a flag that wasn't for him. He stepped forward and the world narrowed. She moved without deciding to. He saw her move and smiled. He did not think she knew him. He had made himself the color of the air. He was wrong.

She touched his arm gently, like a swimmer's, to let him know she was there without making the water choppy. "Leonard," she said, and his name jumped like a fish at the sound.

"Len," he said, and the correction was a reflex he would never lose.

"We should talk."

"I have nothing to say to you," he said but said it like someone who had wanted to talk all his life but had never been invited to, not in his language.

"That note you sent me said plenty," she said lightly. "Color is a debt. Who pays it?"

He looked at the nearest flag. He looked at the nearest child. He looked at her. "Everyone," he said. "If they insist."

And then he ran. Not far. There were people who moved with instincts buffed by years of doing this and they closed it down. He didn't fight like a man who wanted to get away. He fought like a man who wanted to control the composition, to arrange who stood where. He twisted. He shouted and the shout had a lecture in it. He said something about purity, he said something about allowing filth to show their colors in the streets. No slurs, no mess. He made hatred neat with punctuation. She flinched at the words, not because they cut her but because they seemed to cut someone else near her, a boy holding his mother’s hand, and there it was again, the real crime making itself known.

They took him, and he weighed less than he should have. He looked like nothing. He looked like anyone. He looked like the space between.

They had him in a room where the walls were painted a color people probably thought neutral. He sat and folded his fingers as if he were praying. He asked for tea and did not drink it. He looked at the table and saw wood grain. She knew he wanted to draw the lines with his eyes. She took it from him; she sat opposite and told him a story about a girl who could swim across a lake and how she went to a city and swam in lanes because the city didn't offer lakes. He did not like her story. He liked his own. He told it with little polite sentences and only once with a raised voice. He told her that color was for preserving. He told her she was guilty of letting it run into gutters. He told her that boys needed to be cleaned of the filth adults put into their heads. He did not use the word he meant for the men who loved and held and marched. He didn't need to. It was there in the room like a draft.

She asked him about Jamie. He looked at her with disappointment. "Names," he said, "are not the right part of this."

"They are to his parents," she said. "They are to me."

"It is not personal," he said, like that absolved the world. "It's correct."

"You took a child," she said. "You made it personal."

He looked at the ceiling and thought about pies and crucibles and ovens. He said nothing. He smiled once, the sort of smile that makes people compare faces to knives. She felt the thinness in the air then, and reached, in her head, for water.

She left him drinking nothing. She went to the board in her office and put his name in the center of a set of lines. Leonard. Len. Lenn. Lenard. He was everything he called himself. He was everything the city had called him, the goblin layered under jokes. She wrote: He hates quietly. She wrote: He paints to make a case to himself. She wrote: Where would he keep the things he thinks are precious.

The answer came from the stamp-seller, who came to the station with ink on her hands and a look that said she had thought herself weak and now thought she might be something else. "There's a storage unit under the bridge," she said. "You can only get to it at low tide. I keep my extra stamps there because I couldn't afford a proper one. He asked me once where I put my things. I told him. He smiled like he'd told me a joke that I would only get later. I didn't get it until now."
