The hardware store had receipts for boiled linseed that would make someone’s insurer have a day. The caretaker remembered a hand lingering on a window latch as if latches were poetry. The ponies in the analyst’s graphs performed their square dance of digital connections with cheerful surrender. The thread had stripped into rope. They pulled on it and felt it go taut. It did not yet come away in their hands.

Rune called as she was walking across the bridge, not to discuss oils or latches but to send her weather in a photograph so precisely gray you could taste iron filings if you let your tongue imagine. After she thanked the sky, he told her, with the casual air of a man who cannot help turning the day into a lesson, that he had spent a serious apprenticeship once learning about rags. “The boatyard where I was young used to keep a bucket on each bench,” he said, his voice dropping into that fondness he reserved for practicalities. “Not for mess. For soaking cloth that had oil in it. There was a boy burned to the wrists because he thought air was for men, not cotton. He learned. I learned. The bucket had a lid. We had a man with a whistle who would blow it if he saw any rag left proud of its brethren. Sometimes the whistle saved us. Sometimes older men saved us. We owe older men,” he added, and in his grammar of debt that was grace, not a ledger.

“Older men and a bucket,” she said, and he laughed in agreement, a bright short sound like the sun choosing to show itself between tasks. He invited her then, not officially, but in the tone he used for imperative kindness. “Come on Saturday,” he said, as if trains could be conjured by suggestion. “Bring me your shoulders. I will not make hot drinks at an inadequate speed and ask you to do nothing. We will look at a window and decide what north is doing. We will name boats we do not own.”

She shouldn’t have been able to. There were debriefs and a Dyer and a Vane and a boy with worker’s soap under his nails and a man awaiting trial and rags petitioning to kill rooms. But the aftershocks had softened into lists now; there were men who liked forums and there were rooms with windows and she could leave this for two days without the river changing its course out of spite. She booked a flight with the mild guilt of someone who is cheating on the weather. On Friday morning she put the orchids into the sink and told them not to dramatize the watering while she was away. She wrote a note for Lindsey that contained only three dangerous nouns. Dyer. Annex. Nursery. The fourth was cake, which in their system meant eat something and do not be a fool. Lindsey hugged it against her chest like a shield and made a face at her as if to say don’t meet an old cities’ ghosts and marry them.

Stockholm received her with its particular curriculum of light. October there did not sulk. It determined. Rune’s flat had changed very little in the years since she had last sat at his small kitchen table, except the magnet on his fridge was a piece of iron with a story and not a comedy fish, and the postcard he had stuck above the kettle was one she had sent him of the river in her own city, as if geography were a courtesy you could return. He made buns to the exacting rhythm she remembered—measure, of course, but measured with the grace of someone who sees flour as topography. He put on coffee as if coffee were a translation that demanded program notes. After she slept for an hour in a room with a window that observed birches, he took her down to the water.

The men at the Baltic swam less like athletes and more like penance. He had not exaggerated when he wrote that the old ones swam naked as reasons; it was not erotic, not comedy, not political. It was a way of taking inventory in weather. She did not go in; she only watched Rune take the cold and turn it into the shape of himself in the water, a man who had chosen a new wife and a stepdaughter with an accent and a line in her brow that said she would always mistrust furniture. He came out rosy and outrageous and alive and told her to stop being a coward, with the delicacy of a man who had learned when to be rude in service of care. She put her hands in up to the wrist and called it enough. He kissed her hair with the legitimacy that comes with repetition.

On the ferry to the island where he liked to look at lighthouses, he practiced saying guilt and debt and color and claimed there was a folktale about a man who owed the sea three hairs from his head every year or his boat would sink. She offered him a similar English nonsense tale about a man who refused to pay a ferryman and was made to carry pebbles instead of coins until his back broke. They agreed in their polyglot way that debt was a poor metaphor for water and an even poorer one for joy. He said “your parade looked brave,” without asking her to explain how a day of girls with faces painted into tigers could scare a man like Leonard. She said “your buns are too sweet,” without admitting she had stood in her kitchen in England with his tea and his magnet and practiced being alive around suddenly finished stories.

On Sunday he taught her the whistle of the boatyard, which was low and practical; he put two fingers between his teeth and made the sound of men being saved from their own resolve. She put two fingers between hers and could only make air. “You puff like a polite horse,” he said, and clapped his hands once when she managed an undignified squeal that made the women by the jetty look over and look away.

She took back with her, besides buns she would have to declare as something else to a customs man not thrilled by pastry, the correction about rags, the feeling that going home to where her mother had taught herself a new tongue did not erase the other homes, and the right to think of the word north as a friend not an exam. The city she returned to was sulking again in damp, which meant it was relieved to see her because it could be rude without consequences. On her desk was a note from Lindsey with a drawing of a tent with a bat on it that meant someone on nights had found no monsters and had nevertheless told stories. Beneath it, two receipts linked Kemp & Kerr’s ledgers to purchases for the annex—primer, rabbit glue, boiled linseed—delivered to a back door by Dyer’s own hand. Next to that, a scrawl from the analyst in letters squarer than the world deserved: M. Pike’s online name is Heeling, as in boats, as in we get the metaphor. He comments on varnish. He mows an allotment. He is dull in a worrying way.

They brought Dyer in at six on Tuesday morning because men forget to be suspicious at six and because the shop would not yet be open and because sometimes kindness is simply timing. His flat above the store smelled of paint that had been thinned too eagerly and bread gone to sadness. There was a photograph of a dog on the dresser with a ball in its mouth and the date of its death in the frame, the kind of grief that made her want to leave the room so it could be just between dog and man. He talked himself into a myth in the first ten minutes and then out of it in the next five. He had not painted eyes white; he had delivered what men who admired him asked him to deliver and had taken his small fee in the currency of inclusion. He had a threadbare lighthouse patch on a jacket he no longer felt entitled to wear because the boys with better sentences had decided he was more logistics than soul.

“Who told you to put peppermint on it,” Lindsey asked, and he startled because the addition of peppermint to a sentence should not make a person jump and did. “Leonard hates turpentine,” he said, shame warming his ear tips. “He says it smells like negligence. He says mint smells like politeness. Elliot likes mint. He thinks peppermint is a discipline. I thought we were being considerate. I thought we were letting in the right and cleaning the rest.” He closed his eyes with the fatigue of a man caught between wanting to be decent and wanting to be admired by indecent men.

In the second drawer of his kitchen, the one where other people keep takeaway menus and rubber bands, there was a bundle of patches—a handful of lighthouses, a handful of compasses—and a list in generous loops of dates and rooms with north light; the annex, the Sunday school, the courthouse. In the third drawer, under a tea towel, a ledger of receipts with notes in a neat hand about who had paid for what and when. It was not a conspiracy that would thrill a parliament. It was simply a system. He had made meetings possible and had liked the way gratitude made him feel like a good man. He had not thought past the end of a night to the morning’s call to a nursery headteacher or a caretaker with a bucket in her hands and smoke making a poem out of her throat.

They did not give Dyer the luxury of martyrdom. They charged him with being a necessary part of other people’s damage and gave his name to papers that would print it in a font that made men like him look more dangerous than they often are. It was not fair, none of it, and it was exactly right; fairness in the aggregate is always a mess for particular births of harm. Elliot watched from his own small seat in an interview room as they told him they’d be charging him for the chalk and the white journey on a wall. “You can still be a teacher of what not to do,” the analyst told him, and he cried again and said he didn’t want to teach, he wanted to print fish and boats like the stamp-seller but with more detail. “Do both,” Lindsey said, and whether it was a mockery or a mercy was for him to find out.

It was the photograph Jamie gave her that put a small hard jewel into their bag that the case could use in the courtroom’s shallow light. He had come with his father to bring the dragon with the fish eye on thick paper and had also brought, carefully, a second picture on lined exercise book torn out too near the staple. In it, a square had been drawn, and within it a rectangle that could be an iron panel, and beyond that a dark space, and to the side a ladder made of six honest rungs drawn with the earnestness of a boy who has recently learned to make parallel lines. “He told me he kept counting in there,” he said, looking at her to see if she felt impressed at the number of details he had remembered. “He said one day he would show me a trick where the iron sings. You put your foot and then the sound comes through your belly and it makes it soft. He said it corrects noise.” He spoke the word correct like a curse he had overheard and decided to try out in a controlled way.

She looked at the sketch, and then at him, and then at the river’s map in her head. She took Lindsey without telling the superintendent where her feet were going and went to the pumping station where the iron had been taught to hum. She had thought they had emptied that small cathedral of his excuses. They had not. Taped to the underside of a girder, because even small men can learn from movies, was a memory card inside a plastic bag with a label that read 2/9, which could have been a date or could have been a count in a mind that always wanted to put people in rows. On it were three files: one of flags being pulled down by neat hands in the night as if they were laundry taken in because of weather, one of the annex room arranged into lecture, chairs precisely spaced as if chairs themselves could perform virtue, and one of a slow pan across a boy asleep on a camp bed wearing a dinosaur that a man had decided was the wrong dragon and had been wrong again. It was monstrous that this evidence ensured the trial would have something that would make jurors feel the right outrage. It was also a relief that a man who admired neatness kept copies for himself and did not trust the cloud. She felt the bad satisfaction in her bones and refused to name it more than once.

The rest of the week fell into that familiar cadence that makes work feel like a piece of music in a key you can hold. Statements cleaned themselves into coherence, with the coaxing that officers like her know how to apply without making it look like pressure. The Crown drafted a skeleton argument with a row of bullet points that, if translated into ordinary speech, read like common sense instead of outrage, which is how these things must go to last. The press called the movement Restorers even now, as if agreeing to their chosen name meant conceding some territory in public imagination. Someone graffiti’d over the word in the annexe with a different tag that said Rotters in bubble letters, and she didn’t tell anyone that the shape of the letters gave her more joy than it should have. She went to Kemp & Kerr and bought a brush she didn’t need and paid cash, and watched Kerr count it as if counting money had always been his path to considering himself useful to the world. He did not like what had come out of evenings in rooms with his name on the delivery sheet. He liked even less being made to like and hate at the same time. She saw the conflict bruise his face in a way that made him look a decade younger.

Rune wrote her a postcard that arrived two days after she had stayed at his table, the mail’s sense of theatre always being late. It was a lighthouse painting whose paint had come away in the top quarter to reveal that white is never truly white. On the back he had written, in his neat teacher’s hand, the Swedish for bake and for fuel and for light, and had drawn lines between them like a child making constellations. He had added in the corner the word for rag and three exclamation marks, because some warnings deserve punctuation.

They had one more incident before the court took hold of the story and made it theirs. A pub on the corner of a quieter street that had chosen to call itself safe for people who liked people was found in the morning with its chalkboard wiped blank and the words Audit This written on it in the careful childish hand of someone aping severity. There was no paint, no peppermint, no lead. There was a little pile of lighthouse patches on the doorstep like a surrender ceremony performed by someone who could not commit to an actual surrender because the drama would be missed. Ivan walked past and picked one up, stuck it on his own jacket, and carried it into the station where he left it on her desk with the affect of a man returning a live grenade that turned out to be a toy. “Use it for evidence,” he said, and then crushed his hand over his forehead in a gesture that would have been theatrical if it were not a man who had spent a week telling others where to stand finally admitting he had a pain.

The magistrate and then a judge would smooth the narrative into what the law can carry. Jurors would be asked to imagine north light and rooms with rags and peppermint oil on pies as if any of that had to do with guilt. The parade committee would become a paragraph. The boy’s dinosaur would be a line asked to perform too much work in a room that does not like metaphor. They would make it work anyway because the Crown could slice and place and label for an audience who will do its duty better if it has small furniture to arrange in its mind. Hendry, the prosecutor, practiced his questions in a voice like gravel smoothed in a pocket over years. “Why the peppermint, Mr Briggs,” he would say, not interested in the answer for curiosity’s sake but because juries like to be told a little motif that they can hum in the jury room while someone remembers a law from the television and gets it slightly wrong. She sat with him and said the word nicely, the word reluctantly, the word tidy, and he smiled in the way barristers smile when they think they might be able to produce relief from logic.

On a Thursday morning, before all that theatre could begin, she went back to the pool because she was beginning to understand that there were weeks when the lane was as necessary as warrants and statements and receipts. She did the ritual without thinking and then realized that not thinking was the ritual, that counting is a device you use to prevent yourself from narrating, and that not narrating is sometimes the only kindness you can do for your head when the head has watched men try to make their outing into prose. The lifeguard had a new paperback and her face had lost its hostility, perhaps because she had watched the morning news and recognized someone’s shoulders, perhaps because she had had a good breakfast. She put fifty on fifty and then put another fifty on top of that and finished with the particular fatigue that shares a border with satisfaction. On her way out, her phone vibrated like a small fish and it was Rune, sending the photograph he had promised of the dregs of coffee in a mug turned on its side so she could see rings that looked a little like isobars. “I think of you in rings,” he wrote. “I know this is not romantic. It is a navigational compliment.”

She took that into the day like a small heat. Crown would ask her to be tidy and someone’s mother would ask her to be human and the superintendent would ask her to be emblematic and Lindsey would ask her to be hungry and the analyst would ask her to be curious and the man in the hardware store would ask her to be fair and the boy would ask her to be reasonable about dragons. She could be some of those at once and not all. That was the adult arithmetic. She made her lists, the city made its, and between them there was a space where mistakes could become lessons and then, if you were very lucky and very stubborn, become routines. She pinned Jamie’s dragon next to the lighthouse patch and let them look at each other as if the conversation could continue without her.

On Sunday evening, when the air had decided not to rain out of sheer boredom, she met Eva near the railings again. The singer had not learned to sing paint back on brick, but she had collected parents and brushes and together they had made the white into a second skin painted by dozens of hands, and there is something about dozens of hands that makes neatness nervous. The jellyfish were more determined, the wheelbarrow had acquired a little flag with colors that would irritate the men who wanted to correct joy, and above the bearded boat someone had written, in a hand that had taken itself seriously and then not, LETTING IN, not as order but as blessing. Eva looked at it with a property owner’s pride. “Sometimes repetition is the point,” she said. “We will repaint again when they tire and we will tire less quickly, because we get to choose our exhausting.”

Hinsley put her fingers on the cold railing and listened for the iron’s modest song. The river was not a ledger. It did not accept payments or hand you change. It told you what had fallen into it and what it intended to carry and what it would give back when your back was turned because some surprises only succeed when you’re not watching. She thought of Leonard in his cell trying to find north by the light of a strip that hummed a wrong note. She thought of Elliot trying to learn shame without making himself an author of it beyond necessity. She thought of Callum making deliveries for boys with better words and worse courage, and of his dog whose photo made him human without absolving anything. She thought of Rune’s whistle and of older men who saved younger ones with the simple violence of sound. She thought of a boy who would wear a different shirt soon and whose father would never again think a smear of paint on a hoodie meant jeopardy. She thought of being allowed to call herself by two names and being a person for whom both were true. She had learned, perhaps, to breathe in water that was not hers and to make it hers by repetition.

On Monday, court would begin to do what court does, which is to try to make stories hold still long enough for twelve people and a man in a robe to agree what happened. She would sit in a witness box and say sentences in a careful order and make her mouth do stone work. Later in a different time she would get on a flight to Stockholm for two days and call it return instead of running. Now, she walked home along streets that were beginning to think about winter in their gutters, passing the fish stamp on Mara’s wrist as she locked up, passing Kemp & Kerr where a man closed a till as if the sound could scare away ideology, passing a boy with a lighthouse patch sewn unpicked from a jacket and repurposed onto a bag where it looked less like allegiance and more like a souvenir from a museum shop. She put her key into the door and thought of tide tables. She counted, because counting made all the rooms in her head come to a productive quiet. Then she went inside and fed the orchids too much water and laughed at herself and wrote on her noticeboard blow out, count, turn, push, and below it, not in the neatness Leonard had wanted of her but in her swimmer’s scrawl, let in.

Chapter 10

The river had made itself plain again. After a week of courtroom air—dry, filtered, old carpet and old sentences—it felt almost indecent to be reminded that water has no respect for procedure. It breathed under the bridge with its usual disregard for narrative, lifting and setting like a creature whose only duty was to remain alive. She stood for a minute and let it dictate her first rhythm of the morning. Then she went to the pool and made the same bargain she had made every day of the trial: fifty to stop the mind from rehearsing, fifty to prevent the body from pretending it didn’t need tending, and fifty because repetition is a better friend than hope when a room is going to require your mouth to stay in order.

Court had its own lanes. The usher with the voice like a line drawl kept them in parallel. The judge in his soft, battered authority kept the temperature a precise degree above humiliation. The jurors sat with faces that tried too hard to be neutral and therefore revealed themselves as kindly, impatient, entered into service with a humility that made you want to be good for them. Hendry the prosecutor kept his sentences deliberately smaller than his appetite. The defense counsel—Mr Purcell, a man whose hair had learned to be glossy by being spoken to, not by oil—did his best work when he pretended to be disappointed in the world’s lack of neatness.

The day Hinsley took the stand, the room behaved as it always did when a woman who had found a boy is asked to perform finding for an audience. The sound drew close around her like heavy curtains. She looked at the oath card and thought of Rune with two fingers and a whistle, ridiculous and then necessary, and she spoke the promise evenly, as if reading a departure time off a platform that would not leave without her.

Hendry walked her through the maps of events with the same care he used to walk through a boatyard: avoid the rust, keep your hand off the parts that look recently painted. The white van became a rectangle on a photograph, then a rectangle in a yard, then a set of plates that had held other names before. The annex with its north light became a grid of dates and deliveries. The peppermint oil was made tame on a chain-of-custody form. The memory card made the jurors’ eyes dip and flinch in a human wave, and then the room did the decent thing and returned its attention to the labels and the times. She said the word dragon once and did not say the boy’s name; they had agreed on this, and even if they had not, her body would have refused to say it here. She described the chair central in the annex and kept her voice from describing what it was to see an outline of a child waiting to be turned from charcoal into idea. She told them he had planned, that he had chosen spaces where air was polite and light did not shift, that he had hired cleanliness the way some men hire honor.

Purcell stood with a pen making small notes that were more theatre than fact, and then he made a show of not needing them. It was almost charming, the way he admired himself for knowing when to pretend to be untidy. “Inspector,” he said, with a softness that tried to reassign her to his register, “we can agree, can we not, that nothing in this case is vulgar.”

He wanted to draw her into Leonard’s diction without admitting he was doing Leonard’s work for him. She thought of pie tins and peppermint and the particular male obsession with the word vulgar when it wants to perform a purity complicated by hunger. “We can agree nothing was messy by accident,” she said, and watched his mouth do the delicate flinch of a man who has been prevented from rolling his eyes.

He took her through process rather than content, because process can be made coy. Why had she gone to the pumping station the second time. Why had she lifted a panel others might not have noticed. Did she not think it romantic, Inspector, to speak of iron singing. Did she not think she had been primed by the boy’s drawing to hear music where there was only the creak of old metal. Had she misremembered a hum into a hymn.

She breathed out like the pool had taught her, felt the tile in her hand, and looked at the jury rather than at Purcell’s slick assurances. “There is a difference,” she said, and left a space, because men like Purcell cannot stand spaces and will fill them for you if you give them trust. “Between romance and attention. He told the boy the iron sang. The boy told me. I heard it. We found the panel there. The memory card was taped to the underside with a label. You can call it romance. I call it listening to a child.”

He tried the doorcode for River Street again. Had she not encouraged her officers to try a number at many doors until one had opened, as if the city were a toy with a loose latch. Had she not, Inspector, gone looking for north-facing windows like a woman in a poem. She told him there had been warrants. She told him the code had been found in pencil on the back of a canvas and that the law had given them what they needed to test its truth. She did not tell him about stepping on gravel barefoot. She felt the bottom of the lane under her fingers and counted to four.

“And you swim,” he said abruptly, because he had thought of it and could not resist, even as his better self tested the word and told him it was petty. “It is part of your image. Does it not—how did you put it—keep your head from narrating. Is that not a strange thing for a witness to claim.”

She let herself smile because she could see the juror on the end shift his jaw, seeing the trick and disliking it. “I swim at six in the morning,” she said. “I count to make room in my head for other people’s narratives, Mr Purcell. It makes me a better witness. It also makes me intolerant of sloppy lanes.”

The room, starved for a small kindness, allowed itself the human release of laughter. He let it sit because he had to, and because his own joke had been too mean to keep. He moved on. He put to her, as if kindly, that the boy had not been harmed. He said the words camp bed with a mildness that could not help suggesting cleanliness. He said water in a glass with a lid, he said he slept and was not cold, he said dinosaur shirt, which someone in the public seats behind her just audibly exhaled at, and the judge said nothing because judges know sometimes a room needs to breathe even if the official prescription forbids it.

“Mr Purcell,” she said, because Hendry had told her to borrow the names when they needed to be made to belong to her for a second, “a child is not unharmed because the linen is pressed. He was taken from his parents without permission. He was told his dragon was wrong. He was told joy was mess. He was taken to be turned into someone else’s lesson. You can decide to call that clean. We can agree to call it what it is.”

He gave up the clean argument because even he did not wish to hear himself polishing that word again. He gestured at her notes with a flourish of boredom. “You wrote about hate,” he said, as if she had doodled between calls. “You wrote ‘He hates quietly.’ We are not here to try quiet hate, Inspector. We are here to try—what? A man who does not like turpentine.”

“We’re here to try abduction,” she said, turning her own mouth away from the taste of peppermint. “We’re here to try planning. We’re here to talk about the difference between correction and theft.”

He put his pen down. “Thank you, Inspector,” he said, and the thank you had the shape of a dismissal that had not quite achieved its clean line. She stepped down and felt her leg do the small tremble that comes when your body mutinies against your stupidity for having believed you could hold still forever. She caught it with the same hand she used to hold cold water at the end of a lane and it let itself be brought back into line.

In the corridor, Hendry let his shoulders drop their performance. “He wanted to make you the poem,” he said, like a man commenting on wind. “Well done for making yourself a weather report.” Lindsey had two coffees and three words. “You were fine,” she said. “Eat this,” she added, and handed her a biscuit that flaked in the morally ambiguous way of shop biscuits trying to pass for bakery.

Elliot Vane sat in the witness room with his hands arranged as if they were frightened of each other. He had not dressed for court well; his earnestness had chosen his shirt and his shirt had failed him. He looked at Hinsley as if seeking permission to continue existing. “I’ve brought the notebook,” he said, small and belligerent at the same time. “The one with the copied bits. Not because I want to help you. Because I want to stop other boys from finding it in my room and thinking it was clever.”

He put it on the table like an apology and then made himself look at Leonard when his turn came. He spoke about north light because the court had not yet had enough of that phrase. He spoke about standards, about wanting lines to mean something. Purcell tried to make him speak about parades, to catch him praising a day as vulgar and then calling it filthy and then being made to choose. He surprised them all and said, simply, “I don’t like crowds. They make me feel untidy. That isn’t a politics. That’s my nerves.” He looked at her when he said nerves, as if asking whether he could live with that word. She let her mouth do the smallest yes it could manage without being theatrical, and he squared himself as if given back not innocence but the permission to stop pretending purity was a profession.

Callum Dyer was less easy. His decency, such as it was, had been sharpened by shame into a tool he kept turning around in his hands without commitment. He said he liked rooms with rules. He said he delivered because people asked and because he wanted to be included among men whose sentences lined up. He tried to save the patches on his jacket by calling them souvenirs, and then he heard himself and put his hand over the place where a patch had been, the universal gesture for covering a hole you cannot mend in public. Purcell offered him the out of logistics, the romantic word that absolves boys without making them feel small. He did not take it fully. The juror on the end wrote down something and underlined it twice, and she found herself irrationally wanting to know if it was pie, peppermint, north, or simply help.

After lunch, the defense brought a theologian, which was almost funny. He was not that by profession—the bar would never permit such spectacle—but he had written a pamphlet about purity of line in sacred art and the way modern pigments had altered the memory of saints. He delivered very careful sentences about correction that never once mentioned Geoff from the Restorers or Dyer’s till or Elliot’s shame. He had the kind of voice that makes people at parties stand near the radiator and forget to refresh their drinks. Hendry let him have his say and then asked him a single question about boys and pies and whether the word correction absolved you of stealing sugar. The man flushed, which pleased no one, and the judge gently intervened before a metaphor hurt someone.

Mara, the fish-stamp seller, testified with her chin up like a small mast. She did not much like being in a room where men did sentences on her behalf, but she liked that she had not died because of a man who built polite evil. She rolled up her sleeve and showed them the fish on her wrist because the usher had told her to remove jewellery and she had refused to remove that and the judge had ruled, with the weary grace of men who have learned to husband their authority, that drawings do not count as ornaments. She spoke of being watched and done kindness to by men who wanted to make it hurt later. She told them about boxes with ribbons and the way a lie can make your day beautiful for three minutes and then ruin a month. She kept her voice from doing an anger she did not yet feel safe allowing itself, and Hinsley wanted very much to stand behind her the whole time as if a body could be a wall.

The Restorers had sent two sympathizers to sit in the gallery and be ordinary. They were good at that. No cause that aspires to decency will send a man who can only roar. They wore jackets that cost money but did not tell you so. They looked, twice, at Hinsley’s hair when she shook it back after a long answer and decided not to make a note of that because it would cheapen their neatness. Outside, one of their younger boys chalked Audit Now on the pavement at the side entrance in a clean hand and then hovered as if waiting for someone to congratulate him on his copybook. He did not expect the woman with the shanty songs to appear with a bucket and a laugh she refused to swallow and a brush that had painted over worse. She told him to hold the other end of the handle and then made him move his arms, and he looked around for a witness who would find this humiliation delicious and saw only a police officer chewing gum like a sacrament and a cat crossing the road with no respect for court schedules. He dragged water. The chalk made its small tired capitulation. He learned better with his hands than he would have online and kept his mouth quiet in a new way.

That evening, Rune sent her a photograph of a window with ice on its edges doing the old trick of making the world outside look as if it had been painted by a hand that fancied itself better than it was. He wrote two words that in Swedish share a parent and yet disagree like siblings about the dinner table. Dom and döma—judgement and to judge—and then, because he could not help needing to make it usable, he wrote the idiomatic for steady your hands. She read it while a pub spilled men arguing about the match into the street and thought how much of life is deciding which words you are allowed to use in your head without inflaming something that does not need to be set on fire.

On the third day, Leonard chose to speak. It was not wise, according to Purcell, but wise is a poor argument with a man who believes a room is owed his tidiness. He came in like a teacher late to Assembly, with apology arranged as posture. He looked smaller because court reduces all men to the size of their wrists. He spoke about color with a care that, if it had been applied to people, might have saved him. He did not say the words he wanted to say because he had promised Purcell he would dress the hatred in a suit that fit. He said “correct” again and the juror on the end made a mark that looked like the opposite of an exclamation. He said he had taken the boy to teach him quiet and to prepare a lesson for the city that had refused to look where light is faithful. He said the word purity once and then corrected himself in public and said decency, the human synonym that hides the old offense under new paint. He told them he had never harmed a child. He told them he had harmed flags and then had replaced them with his own humility. He told them he had washed tins and folded paper and kept rooms proper and that he had done nothing that did not in the end come down to helping.

Hendry asked him, without touching any of the nouns Leonard had chosen out of his little museum, why the boy had been taken without permission. He asked him whether correction ever needed a key. He asked him if he liked peppermint because peppermint made his fantasies smell polite. Leonard, hungry to show that he had invented every sentence there was in this story, admitted he could have telephoned a parent and told them about dragons and could have invited them to bring the boy to the annex and could have explained north light to them like an uncle who has learned physics without getting dirty. He had not. He believed permission had become vulgar in this city. He did not say vulgar, but he breathed the word, and the room, which had been good to him, changed its mind about him precisely then.

That night, she did not go to the pool. She went to the river and stood in a place where you can see the black water come in under the old brick like a steady unspooling of ribbon. The city had allowed itself a small celebration of propriety on the court steps in the form of a choir that had no permit and did not need one. A woman sang a song in a language Hinsley did not speak and others hummed their acceptance around it. Mara sat on the low wall and stamped her fish by torchlight for children whose parents had decided it was worth being out in the dark if they could be whispered into feeling less alone. Lindsey leaned on a railing in that way she has when she is refusing to rest. The superintendent had gone home to a house that made more noise than he had planned when he designed his life, and the ponytail analyst had taken the long way, because sometimes a bike needs to be ridden not to a destination but to a more useful mood.

On Day Four, the cross-examinations had begun to feel like men trying to braid hair without admitting they envied its gloss. There was a rhythm to version and error that even the judge’s patience could not make fresh. She watched Purcell reach for the same handful of nouns and twist them into new orders and wished for a little salt on the entire enterprise. Then, in the afternoon, the weather gave them something to attend to. The sky darkened too quickly for a day in this month. The lights in the courtroom made everything look like a rehearsal. A child cried outside in a corridor in a way that made every mother in the building flinch with muscle memory, even the ones who had never had children.

There was a smell, faint and wrong, of oil made hot on too-small rags. Her body recognized it before her discipline could make her keep her seat. She stood and said in a steady voice that the usher would approve of, “Your Honour, there may be a small matter outside,” and the judge, who did not like being told about the weather by a witness, nevertheless nodded because his nose had a loyalty to the world his training could not erase. They emptied the court with the clean efficiency of a school drill and found in the service corridor a miracle: a small fire beginning itself without theatre, a handful of cloth that had been used to wipe brushes and then tucked into a corner the way boys tuck guilt into boxes under beds. A young man stood looking at it with honest horror and on his jacket the lighthouse had not yet been unpicked.

“Bucket,” Eva said, because she had arrived like weather and had brought with her that old, practical sound. The caretaker had a bucket because Rune was right: older men and buckets save us. They doused the heat before it could decide to stand up and become a hero. The young man cried and told them he had wanted to show decency with a gesture and had not realized—he had not realized—that the rags had lives beyond paint. His hands shook. He let himself be lectured, which was new. He let himself be escorted out, which would make his online sentences different the next day or not at all.

“Rags,” Lindsey said later, leaning on her desk with all the grace of an exhausted aunt. “Rags will do us in faster than any plan.” Hinsley nodded because she did not know how to answer in a way that would not make her feel clever, and cleverness is the enemy of this work. She thought of Rune, of the whistle, of the bucket, of the boy with the wrists, of the men in their club-making sentences. She texted two words, because Swedish had made her greedy for the economy of certain pairs that do more than their count. Whistle. Bucket. He sent back an address in Stockholm where a bucket could be bought from a man who would look at you and know whether you had learned your lesson about rags and say nothing if you had.

On the last day before the judge took the narrative and gave it the shape his robe demanded, Mara appeared at the back with a parcel tied with string, the sensible kind, not the theatrical rag of ribbon that allows lies to dress as gifts. Inside were stamps she had carved new: boats with dragon eyes, fish with lighthouse fins, small clever things that children could press into wrists and know that they belonged to a city that makes its signs in public because secrets make boys like Leonard believe themselves necessary. She had written a note with printing that took itself seriously because it had decided it had to. For the baby walls, she’d scrawled, as if the sides of buildings were children you could scold and then feed.

Hendry stood to close with a modesty that made the room lean in. He told the jury to put away the romance that men had tried to sell them. He told them to keep the peppermint and the dragon and the north light only insofar as those words helped them see that planning had been done by a mind in love with itself and that a boy had been taken from his name and moved into a room whose cleanliness had no compassion in it. He refused to say the word hate. He refused to say vulgar. He gave them abduction, and then he gave them a single word that had no Latin bones in it, that belonged to mothers who find their children and to men who queue for their bread and to lifeguards with paperbacks and to caretakers with buckets. Take.

Purcell’s closing had angles. He asked them to consider the difference between harm and fear. He asked them to separate songs from evidence. He asked them if the city had not kept its own counsel about what it calls care and whether a man who disapproved of parades might not be guilty simply of a sentence uttered in a the wrong place. He smiled at them in the way men in his line have learned persuades men at parties. He made a small, elegant case for a technical mercy. He did not ever convince the room he had met the boy on the camp bed.

They retired. The jury went to make their small weather upstairs. The building performed the quiet it performs when it wants to remind itself it is a theatre, not a home. Lindsey chewed gum and then produced a fresh stick and then did the kindness of offering it to Purcell, who took it because he had been taught politeness by a woman in a kitchen when he was ten and sometimes those habits rescue courts more than rules do. They did not speak about outcomes. They spoke about buckets and rags because even silk-lined rooms like to pretend they are kinder when they perform the practical.

She did not wait in the corridor with the others. She went down to the ramp that leads to a side door where men with cigarettes socialize their nerves, and she watched the rain decide to be light after all. Mara joined her, because Mara had learned to put herself where edges exist. “If they say no,” Mara said, maybe to see what the word felt like on her tongue, “I will stamp the houses with more fish than they can wash. If they say yes, I will still stamp. It’s not their job to finish these things.”

“It is nobody’s job to finish them,” Hinsley said. “We just put better hinges on the ugly doors.” She thought of the panel at the pumping station and how the lie in the rivet pattern had let a man become neat in a way he had no right to be. She thought of hinges and wanted to be ridiculous and go buy some. She would not. She would go home after and water orchids and count and be ordinary and that, too, would be part of her vocation.

When the verdict came—quickly, because sometimes the city allows itself the decency of ah yes rather than hmm—the word that mattered was the one that had belonged to Hendry and then to her and then to the jurors. Guilty. There would be sentences later about how many years and whether a man who liked north light could be made to live under strip bulbs that cannot help singing. There would be appeals written with courtesy and peeled apart with equal courtesy. There would be boys online who would say standards have fallen and other boys who would delete an app and go to an art room where a woman would put linseed rags in a bucket and teach them something older men had taught her. There would be a parade next year and someone would draw a dragon without asking permission and a man would look at it and decide to keep his mouth closed for once because the room had taught him this type of silence.

She went home because she had learned to give herself home as a prize for not having ruined the day. She put the fish magnet straight because it had decided again to be comedic and look as if it were falling. She poured Rune’s tea for the taste of chemical winter on the tongue and because in a week she would need to be seen in Stockholm again in a kitchen where the light admits its own weather. The orchids looked back at her with their precise ridiculousness. She put a towel on the back of a chair to keep herself from going to bed with wet hair and met the towel’s insistence as if it were a person. Then she sat on the floor with her back against the cabinet and let the day remove itself from her bones inch by careful inch.

Later, when the city had decided to call it night, she walked to the river without needing to as if the water had asked. It made its old sounds and a new one, because verdicts alter the timbre of streets even if they do not change the notes. On the railing, chalk had returned in small abundance. Fish with hearts in their eyes. Dragons whose fire was not red. A lighthouse with a speech bubble that said BUCKETS, which would have made Rune snort and then become solemn. Next to it, someone had written in spelling that had been learned with difficulty and love: CLEAN IS KIND, NOT CRUEL. She stood there until her fingers were cold and then warmed them under her arms like a bird. She counted. She let the counting be the only sentence she chose. Then she went home and slept without rehearsing. In the morning she would swim. In the afternoon she would eat a bun that had too much sugar. In the evening she would look at an old file full of new names. Between those acts she would allow herself one small private vulgarity, which is to say she would go to the museum gift shop and buy a model boat and not assemble it and keep it on a shelf because it is sometimes enough to know that a ship could be made by your hands and to leave it unmade as a way of promising yourself gentler work later.
